title: SSL Not Enforced
extra_info: remediation:the application should instruct web browsers to only access the application using https. to do this, enable http strict transport security (hsts) by adding a response header with the name 'strict-transport-security' and the value 'max-age=expiretime', where expiretime is the time in seconds that browsers should remember that the site should only be accessed using https

title: OTP Brute Force Attack
extra_info:
step1:-capture the login request via proxy.
step2:-enter the wrong otp(eg 123456) and capture the request via proxy.
step3:-now send this otp request to burp intruder.
step4:-now start the brute force attack for 6 digit otp.
step5:-now at the 283rd request we successfully got the correct otp.
step6:- now enter this correct otp(699044) and you will be able to successfully log in.

as the otp is 6 digit number.
so, i passed over the request to the intruder tab to carry out a brute force attack and see if the website allowed multiple attempts for the otp. now, to figure it out i carried out a brute force attack, for the first attempt i saw the otp that i got and made a long list of nearly 300+ number and included correct otp at the very end to just know if the process will work out or not.
at 311th attempt successfully got the correct otp.
refer poc for further details.

payment bypass ios production environment: 

an application has payment integration which is used for payment of different products(mutual funds, insurance,etc…) and transaction for purchasing products online. where an attacker tampers the request/response parameter data to exploit transactions.

payment bypass ios prod:

in this scenario we are able to purchase mutual funds having value rs 10000 and have successfully received an email confirmation of a lump sum payment of ₹ 10,000 towards the following scheme without paying any amount(i.e no money is debited from my bank account). 

scheme : axis long term equity direct plan-growth
order id: 101-0110153-0001692
applicable nav allocation date: apr. 27th, 2020
expected date: apr. 28th, 2020

verify checksum.
don’t take an amount value from the user at the final payment page.
the dependency of payment success and failure is on parameters rather than checksum.it should be verified by success/failure checksum on the server side after that send this to the user.

step 1 : select the product that you want to purchase(here we are purchasing mutual fund).
step2:- enter the amount for the mutual fund purchase.
step3:- now proceed to payment.
step4:- enter your upi details linked with your bank account and proceed.
step5:- initiate payment request and you will receive upi request of rs10000 on your upi app.
step6:- cancel the transaction in application and capture this payment request via proxy.
step7:- now edit the post request(web/payments/centralpaymentcomplete.js) parameters:
“responsecode”: pf009 to pf008
“description”:payment cancelled by user to payment successful by user.
“transactionstatus”: 1 to 2
“transactionattemptstatus”: 3 to 2
step8:-now forward this edited request.
step9:- the transaction is successful and i received the confirmation mail for my purchase.
steps_to_reproduce:
step 1 : select the product that you want to purchase(here we are purchasing mutual fund).
step2:- enter the amount for the mutual fund purchase.
step3:- now proceed to payment.
step4:- enter your upi details linked with your bank account and proceed.
step5:- initiate payment request and you will receive upi request of rs10000 on your upi app.
step6:- cancel the transaction in application and capture this payment request via proxy.
step7:- now edit the post request(web/payments/centralpaymentcomplete.js) parameters:
“responsecode”: pf009 to pf008
“description”:payment cancelled by user to payment successful by user.
“transactionstatus”: 1 to 2
“transactionattemptstatus”: 3 to 2
step8:-now forward this edited request.
step9:- the transaction is successful and i received the confirmation mail for my purchase.
mitigation:
verify checksum.
don’t take an amount value from the user at the final payment page.
the dependency of payment success and failure is on parameters rather than checksum.it should be verified by success/failure checksum on the server side after that send this to the user.

verify checksum.
don’t take an amount value from the user at the final payment page.
the dependency of payment success and failure is on parameters rather than checksum.it should be verified by success/failure checksum on the server side after that send this to the user.

extra_info:
complete or few parts of application  transmits sensitive critical data in cleartext in an unencrypted http communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.
many communication channels can be "sniffed" by attackers during data transmission. for example, network traffic can often be sniffed by any attacker who has access to a network interface. this significantly lowers the difficulty of exploitation by attackers.

provided apk is ssl pinned and running over https communication channel but few url is running over http :

host : uatpg55.etmoney.techweb/payments/user/create-payment
host : cauatinsweb218.etmoney.tech/api/ca-insurance/verify-proposal-url
host : cauatinsweb218.etmoney.tech/api/ca-insurance/send-otp
host : cauatinsweb218.etmoney.tech/api/ca-insurance/verify-otp

encrypt the data with a reliable encryption scheme before transmitting.
when using web/mobile applications with ssl, use ssl for the entire session from login to logout, not just for the initial login page.
use tls 1.2
use wireshark packet sniffer tool on same network

form action hijacking vulnerabilities arise when an application places user-supplied input into the action url of an html form. an attacker can use this vulnerability to construct a url that, if visited by another application user, will modify the action url of a form to point to the attacker's server. if a user submits the form then its contents, including any input from the victim user, will be delivered directly to the attacker. even if the user doesn't enter any sensitive information, the form may still deliver a valid csrf token to the attacker, enabling them to perform csrf attacks. in some cases web browsers may help exacerbate this issue by autocompleting forms with previously entered user input.
we are able to inject malicious url in et money payment create page.
consider hard-coding the form action url, or implementing a whitelist of allowed values.

step 1 : select the product that you want to purchase(here we are purchasing mutual fund).
step2:- enter the amount for the mutual fund purchase.
step3:- now proceed to payment.
step4:- capture the payment request (/web/payments/user/create-payment).
step5:- now edit the post request parameter: (returnurl) with malicious url.
step6:- insert malicious url
step7:- forward the request.
step8:- malicious url successfully injected and we can see the page in etmoney webview.

extra_info: many mobile applications use sqlite db to store data on client devices. on that time they may be store sensitive information like credit debit card details, payment history, credentials, emails, phone numbers, secret token etc...
we have observed sensitive information stored in sqlltedb on android device.
do not store any sensitive data on the device. if there any business requirement then keep it encrypted
using rooted devices we can get application package folder from data>data folder

we have observed that et money application does not verify cors domain and we are able to inject any domain,

many modern websites use cors to allow access from subdomains and trusted third parties. their implementation of cors may contain mistakes or be overly lenient to ensure that everything works, and this can result in exploitable vulnerabilities

cors vulnerabilities arise primarily as misconfigurations. prevention is therefore a configuration problem. the following sections describe some effective defenses against cors attacks.
 proper configuration of cross-domain requests: if a web resource contains sensitive information, the origin should be properly specified in the access-control-allow-origin header. 
only allow trusted sites: it may seem obvious but origins specified in the access-control-allow-origin header should only be sites that are trusted. in particular, dynamically reflecting origins from cross-domain requests without validation is readily exploitable and should be avoided. 
avoid whitelisting null: avoid using the header access-control-allow-origin: null. cross-domain resource calls from internal documents and sandboxed requests can specify the null origin. cors headers should be properly defined in respect of trusted origins for private and public servers. 
avoid wildcards in internal networks : avoid using wildcards in internal networks. trusting network configuration alone to protect internal resources is not sufficient when internal browsers can access untrusted external domains. 
cors is not a substitute for server-side security policies: cors defines browser behaviors and is never a replacement for server-side protection of sensitive data - an attacker can directly forge a request from any trusted origin. therefore, web servers should continue to apply protections over sensitive data, such as authentication and session management, in addition to properly configured cors.
steps_to_reproduce: refer poc:

 proper configuration of cross-domain requests: if a web resource contains sensitive information, the origin should be properly specified in the access-control-allow-origin header. 
only allow trusted sites: it may seem obvious but origins specified in the access-control-allow-origin header should only be sites that are trusted. in particular, dynamically reflecting origins from cross-domain requests without validation is readily exploitable and should be avoided. 
avoid whitelisting null: avoid using the header access-control-allow-origin: null. cross-domain resource calls from internal documents and sandboxed requests can specify the null origin. cors headers should be properly defined in respect of trusted origins for private and public servers. 
avoid wildcards in internal networks : avoid using wildcards in internal networks. trusting network configuration alone to protect internal resources is not sufficient when internal browsers can access untrusted external domains. 
cors is not a substitute for server-side security policies: cors defines browser behaviors and is never a replacement for server-side protection of sensitive data - an attacker can directly forge a request from any trusted origin. therefore, web servers should continue to apply protections over sensitive data, such as authentication and session management, in addition to properly configured cors.

title: Insecure Deserialization
extra_info:
complex modern systems are highly distributed. as the components communicate with each other and share information (such as moving data between services, storing information, etc), the native binary format is not ideal. in short, serialization is the process of turning this binary data into a string (ascii characters) so it can be moved using standard protocols.

serialization operations are extremely common in architectures that include apis, microservices, and client-side mvc. when the data being serialized and deserialized is trusted (under the control of the system), there are no risks.

however, when the input can be modified by the user, the result is an untrusted deserialization vulnerability. in this case, the conversion back from string to binary (deserialization) is a delicate operation prone to abuse. the typical course of action is to prepare a payload that includes remote code execution in the targeted machine. often, the goal is to run system commands.

any serialized data used by an application is at risk of manipulation, so ideally it should be accompanied by a cryptographic signature that enables integrity checks. this validation would prevent tampering of the serialized data. another mitigation strategy includes not using binary formats, and choose alphanumeric standardized formats such as json and yaml.
sdfdfdsds
sdfdsfdsfdsfds
sdfdsfdsfs

the best way to protect your web application from this type of risk is not to accept serialized objects from untrusted sources.

if you can’t do this, owasp provides more technical recommendations that you (or your developers) can try to implement:

implementing integrity checks such as digital signatures on any serialized objects to prevent hostile object creation or data tampering.
enforcing strict type constraints during deserialization before object creation as the code typically expects a definable set of classes. bypasses to this technique have been demonstrated, so reliance solely on this is not advisable.
isolating and running code that deserializes in low privilege environments when possible.
logging deserialization exceptions and failures, such as where the incoming type is not the expected type, or the deserialization throws exceptions.
restricting or monitoring incoming and outgoing network connectivity from containers or servers that deserialize.
monitoring deserialization, alerting if a user deserializes constantly.

title: Clickjacking Attack
extra_info:
clickjacking is an attack that tricks a user into clicking a webpage element which is invisible or disguised as another element. this can cause users to unwittingly download malware, visit malicious web pages, provide credentials or sensitive information, transfer money, or purchase products online.
typically, clickjacking is performed by displaying an invisible page or html element, inside an iframe, on top of the page the user sees. the user believes they are clicking the visible page but in fact they are clicking an invisible element in the additional page transposed on top of it.

referral: https://owasp.org/www-community/attacks/cross_site_tracing

step1:-created an html page and attempt to include a sensitive page from your website in an iframe. 

note: refer poc

title: Host header Injection
extra_info: http://192.168.26.119:8383/abinbev/addrfill is vulnerable to host header injection because the host header can be changed to something outside the target domain (ie. www.msn.com) and cause it to redirect to to that domain instead (see below).

first, go to the url of http://192.168.26.119:8383/abinbev/addrfill
later intercept the response of the particular url using burp suite proxy tool
spider the host to get the 302-redirect page and intercept the request with burp suite
here i have changed the hostname from openedx.microsoft.com to bing.com in response the location is changed to https://msn.com
i have also enclosed the poc for your reference,

target host is http://192.168.26.119:8383

here i have changed the target host of http://192.168.26.119:8383 to msn.com

 the page gets redirected to the 404 response page of msn.com

refer proof of concept for screenshots.

title: URL Injection Via Host Header Injection
description: URL Injection Via Host Header Injection
extra_info:
application is vulnerable to host header injection because the host header can be changed to something outside the target domain (ie. ivr.activeconnect.in) and cause it to redirect to to that domain instead (see below).

attack vectors are somewhat limited but depends on how the host header is used by the back-end application code. if code references the hostname used in the url such as password reset pages, an attacker could spoof the host header of the request in order to trick the application to forwarding the password reset email to the attackers domain instead, etc. other attack vectors may also be possible through manipulation of hyperlinks or other misc. code that relies on the host/domain of the request.

step5:- click on dashboard you will get redirected to msn.com.

title: Insecure Deserialization
extra_info:
complex modern systems are highly distributed. as the components communicate with each other and share information (such as moving data between services, storing information, etc), the native binary format is not ideal. in short, serialization is the process of turning this binary data into a string (ascii characters) so it can be moved using standard protocols.

serialization operations are extremely common in architectures that include apis, microservices, and client-side mvc. when the data being serialized and deserialized is trusted (under the control of the system), there are no risks.

however, when the input can be modified by the user, the result is an untrusted deserialization vulnerability. in this case, the conversion back from string to binary (deserialization) is a delicate operation prone to abuse. the typical course of action is to prepare a payload that includes remote code execution in the targeted machine. often, the goal is to run system commands.

any serialized data used by an application is at risk of manipulation, so ideally it should be accompanied by a cryptographic signature that enables integrity checks. this validation would prevent tampering of the serialized data. another mitigation strategy includes not using binary formats, and choose alphanumeric standardized formats such as json and yaml.

the best way to protect your web application from this type of risk is not to accept serialized objects from untrusted sources.

if you can’t do this, owasp provides more technical recommendations that you (or your developers) can try to implement:

implementing integrity checks such as digital signatures on any serialized objects to prevent hostile object creation or data tampering.
enforcing strict type constraints during deserialization before object creation as the code typically expects a definable set of classes. bypasses to this technique have been demonstrated, so reliance solely on this is not advisable.
isolating and running code that deserializes in low privilege environments when possible.
logging deserialization exceptions and failures, such as where the incoming type is not the expected type, or the deserialization throws exceptions.
restricting or monitoring incoming and outgoing network connectivity from containers or servers that deserialize.
monitoring deserialization, alerting if a user deserializes constantly.

http request smuggling: 
http request smuggling is a technique for interfering with the way a web site processes sequences of http requests that are received from one or more users. request smuggling vulnerabilities are often critical in nature, allowing an attacker to bypass security controls, gain unauthorized access to sensitive data, and directly compromise other application users.

when the front-end server forwards http requests to a back-end server, it typically sends several requests over the same back-end network connection, because this is much more efficient and performant. the protocol is very simple: http requests are sent one after another, and the receiving server parses the http request headers to determine where one request ends and the next one begins.
in this situation, it is crucial that the front-end and back-end systems agree about the boundaries between requests. otherwise, an attacker might be able to send an ambiguous request that gets interpreted differently by the front-end and back-end systems.
here, the attacker causes part of their front-end request to be interpreted by the back-end server as the start of the next request. it is effectively prepended to the next request, and so can interfere with the way the application processes that request. this is a request smuggling attack, and it can have devastating results.
if the front-end and back-end servers behave differently in relation to the (possibly obfuscated) transfer-encoding header, then they might disagree about the boundaries between successive requests, leading to request smuggling vulnerabilities.

here we are able to inject malicious xss payload and html injection.

http request smuggling vulnerabilities arise in situations where a front-end server forwards multiple requests to a back-end server over the same network connection, and the protocol used for the back-end connections carries the risk that the two servers disagree about the boundaries between requests. some generic ways to prevent http request smuggling vulnerabilities arising are as follows:

disable reuse of back-end connections, so that each back-end request is sent over a separate network connection.
use http/2 for back-end connections, as this protocol prevents ambiguity about the boundaries between requests.
use exactly the same web server software for the front-end and back-end servers, so that they agree about the boundaries between requests.
in some cases, vulnerabilities can be avoided by making the front-end server normalize ambiguous requests or making the back-end server reject ambiguous requests and close the network connection. however, these approaches are potentially more error-prone than the generic mitigations identified above.

request smuggling attacks involve placing both the content-length header and the transfer-encoding header into a single http request and manipulating these so that the front-end and back-end servers process the request differently. the exact way in which this is done depends on the behavior of the two servers:

cl.te: the front-end server uses the content-length header and the back-end server uses the transfer-encoding header.
te.cl: the front-end server uses the transfer-encoding header and the back-end server uses the content-length header.
te.te: the front-end and back-end servers both support the transfer-encoding header, but one of the servers can be induced not to process it by obfuscating the header in some way.
steps_to_reproduce:
request smuggling attacks involve placing both the content-length header and the transfer-encoding header into a single http request and manipulating these so that the front-end and back-end servers process the request differently. the exact way in which this is done depends on the behavior of the two servers:

cl.te: the front-end server uses the content-length header and the back-end server uses the transfer-encoding header.
te.cl: the front-end server uses the transfer-encoding header and the back-end server uses the content-length header.
te.te: the front-end and back-end servers both support the transfer-encoding header, but one of the servers can be induced not to process it by obfuscating the header in some way.
mitigation:
http request smuggling vulnerabilities arise in situations where a front-end server forwards multiple requests to a back-end server over the same network connection, and the protocol used for the back-end connections carries the risk that the two servers disagree about the boundaries between requests. some generic ways to prevent http request smuggling vulnerabilities arising are as follows:

disable reuse of back-end connections, so that each back-end request is sent over a separate network connection.
use http/2 for back-end connections, as this protocol prevents ambiguity about the boundaries between requests.
use exactly the same web server software for the front-end and back-end servers, so that they agree about the boundaries between requests.
in some cases, vulnerabilities can be avoided by making the front-end server normalize ambiguous requests or making the back-end server reject ambiguous requests and close the network connection. however, these approaches are potentially more error-prone than the generic mitigations identified above.

title: Host header Injection
extra_info:
attack vectors are somewhat limited but depends on how the host header is used by the back-end application code. if code references the hostname used in the url such as password reset pages, an attacker could spoof the host header of the request in order to trick the application to forwarding the password reset email to the attackers domain instead, etc.other attack vectors may also be possible through manipulation of hyperlinks or other misc. code that relies on the host/domain of the request.

reference: https://www.briskinfosec.com/blogs/blogsdetail/host-header-attack

here i have changed the hostname from https://dbuat.generalmobi.mobi/ to www.msn.com
in response the location is changed to www.msn.com.
later i captured the response via proxy and opened it in a browser, the page gets redirected  to the 404 response page of www.msn.com.
note refer poc:

title: URL Injection via Host Header injection
description: URL Injection via Host Header injection
extra_info:
the host header is reflected in the response body and that a part of the location header can be manipulated via user input.
reference: https://www.briskinfosec.com/blogs/blogsdetail/host-header-attack
an hacker can modify the legitimate host header with the vulnerable host in the request.using this attacker successfully inject the link and redirect the user to the domain of the hacker.

title: Clickjacking Attack
extra_info:
clickjacking is an attack that tricks a user into clicking a webpage element which is invisible or disguised as another element. this can cause users to unwittingly download malware, visit malicious web pages, provide credentials or sensitive information, transfer money, or purchase products online.
typically, clickjacking is performed by displaying an invisible page or html element, inside an iframe, on top of the page the user sees. the user believes they are clicking the visible page but in fact they are clicking an invisible element in the additional page transposed on top of it.

title: HTML Injection
extra_info: html injection is an attack that is similar to cross-site scripting (xss). while in the xss vulnerability the attacker can inject and execute javascript code, the html injection attack only allows the injection of certain html tags. when an application does not properly handle user supplied data, an attacker can supply valid html code, typically via a parameter value, and inject their own content into the page. this attack is typically used in conjunction with some form of social engineering, as the attack is exploiting a code-based vulnerability and a user's trust

impact:- this vulnerability can have many consequences, like disclosure of a user's session
cookies that could be used to impersonate the victim, or, more generally, it can allow the
attacker to modify the page content seen by the victims.

mitigation : script should filter metacharacters from user input.

extra_info: the risk here is that a web client can put any value into the origin request http header in order to force the web application to provide it the target resource content. in the case of a browser web client, the header value is managed by the browser but another “web client” can be used (like curl/wget/burp suite/…) to change/override the “origin” header value. for this reason, it is not recommended to use the origin header to authenticate requests as coming from your site.

extra_info: an attacker gains access to application, service, or device with the privileges of an authorized or privileged user by evading or circumventing an authentication mechanism. the attacker is therefore able to access protected data without authentication ever having taken place. this refers to an attacker gaining access equivalent to an authenticated user without ever going through an authentication procedure. this is usually the result of the attacker using an unexpected access procedure that does not go through the proper checkpoints where authentication should occur. for example, a web site might assume that all users will click through a given link in order to get to secure material and simply authenticate everyone that clicks the link. however, an attacker might be able to reach secured web content by explicitly entering the path to the content rather than clicking through the authentication link, thereby avoiding the check entirely. this attack pattern differs from other authentication attacks in that attacks of this pattern avoid authentication entirely, rather than faking authentication by exploiting flaws or by stealing credentials from legitimate users.
we are able to bypass authentication flow via manipulating request skipotp parameter code.

never depend on status code 0, 1 or true , fails, success , fails code. remove skipotp.
and implement strong authentication server side validation and use min 6 digit otp with rate limit
steps_to_reproduce: change skipotp 0 to 1
mitigation:
never depend on status code 0, 1 or true , fails, success , fails code. remove skipotp.
and implement strong authentication server side validation and use min 6 digit otp with rate limit

title: Clickjacking Attack
extra_info:
clickjacking is an interface-based attack in which a user is tricked into clicking on an actionable content on a hidden website by clicking on some other content in a decoy website. also known as "ui redress attack".

it is an attack that tricks a user into clicking a webpage element which is invisible or disguised as another element. this can cause users to unwittingly download malware, visit malicious web pages, provide credentials or sensitive information, transfer money, or purchase products online.

typically, clickjacking is performed by displaying an invisible page or html element, inside an iframe, on top of the page the user sees. the user believes they are clicking the visible page but in fact they are clicking an invisible element in the additional page transposed on top of it.

the invisible page could be a malicious page, or a legitimate page the user did not intend to visit (which has been happening alot recently).

using a similar technique, keystrokes can also be hijacked. with a carefully crafted combination of stylesheets, iframes, and text boxes, a user can be led to believe they are typing in the password to their email or bank account, but are instead typing into an invisible frame controlled by the hacker.

remote code execution (rce) refers to the ability of a cyberattacker to access and make changes to a computer owned by another, without authority and regardless of where the computer is geographically located.

rce allows an attacker to take over a computer or a server by running arbitrary malicious code (malware). "rce (remote code execution) vulnerabilities are one of the most dangerous of its kind as attackers may execute malicious code in the vulnerable server,"

timely patching or timely installation of software update ranks as the top cybersecurity measure in preventing remote code execution attacks.

for instance, to prevent remote code execution via cve-2018-8248 vulnerability, microsoft’s june 12, 2018 security update has to be installed. in the case of wannacry cyberattack, remote code execution via the exploitation of microsoft windows smb vulnerability could have been prevented if only microsoft’s march 2017 security update had been timely applied.

to prevent attackers trying to infect vulnerable servers with cryptocurrency mining malware, the initial attack must be blocked. as an initial attack, cybercriminals typically exploit remote code execution vulnerabilities to launch their malware, similar to what wannacry attackers did.

if your organization is using computers or servers that are known to be using software that’s vulnerable to remote code execution, the latest vendor patch to mitigate this particular cyberattack should be timely applied.

title: HTML Injection
extra_info: html injection is an attack that is similar to cross-site scripting (xss). while in the xss vulnerability the attacker can inject and execute javascript code, the html injection attack only allows the injection of certain html tags. when an application does not properly handle user supplied data, an attacker can supply valid html code, typically via a parameter value, and inject their own content into the page. this attack is typically used in conjunction with some form of social engineering, as the attack is exploiting a code-based vulnerability and a user's trust

impact:- this vulnerability can have many consequences, like disclosure of a user's session
cookies that could be used to impersonate the victim, or, more generally, it can allow the
attacker to modify the page content seen by the victims.

mitigation : script should filter metacharacters from user input.

goto customq section
goto email template section.
enter any html code in the subject field.
refer poc

your script should filter metacharacters from user input.
the main rule to prevent html attack is appropriate data validation.
every input should be checked if it contains any script code or any html code.

title: Broken Access Control
extra_info:
a critical vulnerability has been discovered, which can be exploited to avail full score on any coding problem.
please find the details below:

reason:
at the time of code compilation, the input and output files are present inside the container. it took a few minutes to figure out the file path pattern.
this pattern remains the same for all the problem statements.
then i wrote a simple python script to redirect output results from the file to stdout.

in case there are multiple input & output files, i calculate md5 hash from the stdin, and match it with the files, and use the corresponding output file in the stdout. 



steps to reproduce:

1. use the below code snippet and compile / submit for any problem statement.


import os
import sys
import subprocess
import hashlib

def make_streams_binary():
    sys.stdin  = sys.stdin.detach()
    sys.stdout = sys.stdout.detach()
    
def md5(fname):
    hash_md5 = hashlib.md5()
    for line in sys.stdin:
            hash_md5.update(line)
    p = 'find . -name "*.txt" -exec cksum {} \+'
    return hash_md5.hexdigest()

def main():
    make_streams_binary()
    chksu = md5(sys.stdin)
    cmd = "cd /tmp ; tmp=$( find . -type f -name *.txt -exec md5sum {} + | grep "  + chksu + " |  sed 's/input*/output/'  ) ; echo $tmp;"
    direct_output = subprocess.check_output(cmd, shell=true ).decode("latin").strip()
    with open("/tmp/" + direct_output.split(" ")[-1] , 'rb') as f:
        for line in f:
            sys.stdout.write(line)

2. on submission, you'll get a full score.

main()

then i wrote a simple python script to redirect output results from the file to stdout.

in case there are multiple input & output files, i calculate md5 hash from the stdin, and match it with the files, and use the corresponding output file in the stdout. 



steps to reproduce:

import os

def make_streams_binary():

def md5(fname):
    hash_md5 = hashlib.md5()
    for line in sys.stdin:
            hash_md5.update(line)
    p = 'find . -name "*.txt" -exec cksum {} \+'
    return hash_md5.hexdigest()

def main():
    make_streams_binary()
    chksu = md5(sys.stdin)
    cmd = "cd /tmp ; tmp=$( find . -type f -name *.txt -exec md5sum {} + | grep "  + chksu + " |  sed 's/input*/output/'  ) ; echo $tmp;"
    direct_output = subprocess.check_output(cmd, shell=true ).decode("latin").strip()
    with open("/tmp/" + direct_output.split(" ")[-1] , 'rb') as f:
        for line in f:
            sys.stdout.write(line)

import os
'''
    for the given path, get the list of all files in the directory tree 
'''
def getlistoffiles(dirname):
    # create a list of file and sub directories 
    # names in the given directory 
    listoffile = os.listdir(dirname)
    allfiles = list()
    # iterate over all the entries
    for entry in listoffile:
        # create full path
        fullpath = os.path.join(dirname, entry)
        # if entry is a directory then get the list of files in this directory 
        if os.path.isdir(fullpath):
            allfiles = allfiles + getlistoffiles(fullpath)
        else:
            allfiles.append(fullpath)
                
    return allfiles        
def main():
    
    dirname = '/var/log';
    
    # get the list of all files in directory tree at given path
    listoffiles = getlistoffiles(dirname)
    
    # print the files
    for elem in listoffiles:
        print(elem)
    print ("****************")
    
    # get the list of all files in directory tree at given path
    listoffiles = list()
    for (dirpath, dirnames, filenames) in os.walk(dirname):
        listoffiles += [os.path.join(dirpath, file) for file in filenames]
        
        
    # print the files    
    for elem in listoffiles:
        print(elem)    
        
        
        
        
if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

title: Broken Access Control
extra_info:
your application should have a consistent and easy to analyze authorization module that is invoked from all your business functions. frequently, such protection is provided by one or more components external to the application code. 
• the enforcement mechanism(s) should deny all access by default, requiring explicit grants to specific roles for access to every function. 
• review your api endpoints against function level authorization flaws, while keeping in mind the business logic of the application and groups hierarchy. 
• make sure that all of your administrative controllers inherit from an administrative abstract controller that implements authorization checks based on the user’s group/role. 
• make sure that administrative functions inside a regular controller implements authorization checks based on the user’s group and role.

step1:- change the x-primary header value and and primaryid parameter value to add or update consent of any user with any arbitrary authorization  header value.
step2:- attacker can change the product code and consent text and agree parameter and can successfully save and update the user consent.
steps_to_reproduce:
step1:- change the x-primary header value and and primaryid parameter value to add or update consent of any user with any arbitrary authorization  header value.
step2:- attacker can change the product code and consent text and agree parameter and can successfully save and update the user consent.
mitigation:
your application should have a consistent and easy to analyze authorization module that is invoked from all your business functions. frequently, such protection is provided by one or more components external to the application code. 
• the enforcement mechanism(s) should deny all access by default, requiring explicit grants to specific roles for access to every function. 
• review your api endpoints against function level authorization flaws, while keeping in mind the business logic of the application and groups hierarchy. 
• make sure that all of your administrative controllers inherit from an administrative abstract controller that implements authorization checks based on the user’s group/role. 
• make sure that administrative functions inside a regular controller implements authorization checks based on the user’s group and role.

title: SSRF
extra_info:
a successful ssrf attack can often result in unauthorized actions or access to data within the organization, either in the vulnerable application itself or on other back-end systems that the application can communicate with. in some situations, the ssrf vulnerability might allow an attacker to perform arbitrary command execution.

an ssrf exploit that causes connections to external third-party systems might result in malicious onward attacks that appear to originate from the organization hosting the vulnerable application, leading to potential legal liabilities and reputational damage.

make sure you know all the possible flows to authenticate to the api (mobile/ web/deep links that
implement one-click authentication/etc.)
ask your engineers what flows you missed.
read about your authentication mechanisms. make sure you understand what and how they are used.
oauth is not authentication, and neither is api keys.
don't reinvent the wheel in authentication, token generation, password storage. use the standards.
credential recovery/forget password endpoints should be treated as login endpoints in terms of brute
force, rate limiting, and lockout protections.
use the owasp authentication cheatsheet.
where possible, implement multi-factor authentication.

title: No issues were found
extra_info:
write description
no issues were found

et is organizing etauto ev conclave 2021 | march 16-17, 2021. here delegates can book their seats by going to book your seat option.  for a single delegate, it costs rs 1768.82 inc gst and no other discount code is available for more discount for a normal user. but here a malicious user can book a seat at rs 1.77 by tampering parameter.

don’t rely on controls which depend on the browser — don’t depend on client-side validation and storing in the browser. 
when the product is added in the cart calculate hash for the total request and compare with the backend so that if any manipulation happened in the request for any value it is different from the server's hash. 
validate input for improper characters and data types. specifically for this case, we can keep a check for quantity with decimal range. keeping range from 1–10 since the max value is defined we can define minimum value. always define the maximum as well as minimum value that the application will accept.

step1:- click on book your seat tab and fill your details. for a single delegate, the booking amount is rs 1768.82 inc gst. 
step2:- now apply any arbitrary coupon code and capture this request via proxy. 
step3:- now change value of the parameter ticket_count=1 to ticket_count=.01 and forward this request.
step4:- now click on pay now and capture this request via proxy.
step5:- now change the parameter qty=1 to qty=.01 and forward this request.
step6:-  now at the final payment page the final amount to be paid is rs 1.77. i have selected upi as payment mode for completing this transaction and successfully got the upi request of rs 1.77 on phonepe.

title: CSRF Attack
extra_info:
cross-site request forgery, also known as csrf, sea surf, or xsrf, is an attack whereby an attacker tricks a victim into performing actions on their behalf. the impact of the attack depends on the level of permissions that the victim has. such attacks take advantage of the fact that a website completely trusts a user once it can confirm that the user is indeed who they say they are.
cross-site request forgery (also known as csrf) is a web security vulnerability that allows an attacker to induce users to perform actions that they do not intend to perform. it allows an attacker to partly circumvent the same origin policy, which is designed to prevent different websites from interfering with each other.

cross-site request forgery is considered a sleeping giant in the world of web application security. it is often not taken as seriously as it should even though it can prove to be a stealthy and powerful attack if executed properly. it is also a common attack, which is why it has secured a spot on the owasp top 10 list several times in a row. however, an exploited cross-site scripting vulnerability (xss) is more of a risk than any csrf vulnerability because csrf attacks have a major limitation. csrf only allows for state changes to occur and therefore the attacker cannot receive the contents of the http response.

the most robust way to defend against csrf attacks is to include a csrf token within relevant requests. the token should be:

unpredictable with high entropy, as for session tokens in general.
tied to the user's session.
strictly validated in every case before the relevant action is executed.

endpoints that perform few critical operations (editing / saving new data) do not have a protection mechanism against csrf attacks. ideally, csrf token should be used to fix this issue.

title: Authentication Bypass
extra_info: an attacker gains access to application, service, or device with the privileges of an authorized or privileged user by evading or circumventing an authentication mechanism. the attacker is therefore able to access protected data without authentication ever having taken place. this refers to an attacker gaining access equivalent to an authenticated user without ever going through an authentication procedure. this is usually the result of the attacker using an unexpected access procedure that does not go through the proper checkpoints where authentication should occur. for example, a web site might assume that all users will click through a given link in order to get to secure material and simply authenticate everyone that clicks the link. however, an attacker might be able to reach secured web content by explicitly entering the path to the content rather than clicking through the authentication link, thereby avoiding the check entirely. this attack pattern differs from other authentication attacks in that attacks of this pattern avoid authentication entirely, rather than faking authentication by exploiting flaws or by stealing credentials from legitimate users.

authentication token  is using "sso_id" as client;s identify. since, sso_id is a publicly known user identifier, auth_token can be forged to impersonate any other user.
this leads to:
1. accessing stored credit card details / tokens
2. account & wallet balance
3. make a transaction on behalf of any other user
user ticket_id / encrypted token instead of sso_id

1. generate auth token for any other user using:
https://staging.timesprime.com/api/generatehash?pid=web
{"ssoid":"7de64pub9jp00ujyzwfg3haf7","mobile":"9425813670","ticketid":"72b00de9c87e4788afa042c1ae85211b","email":"prakhar.agnihotri@timesinternet.in","merchantid":"times_prime"}

replace sso_id with the target  user's identifty

2.  get auth_token in the response
{"hh":"16a7b2857949a947082992fc74a7ca5ef946d6310ee12832d28648de1cbf","mobno":"9425813670","ticketid":"5b00d19c87e4788afa042c1ae85211b","timestamp":"1611040623749","uemail":"prakhar.agnihotri@timesinternet.in","uid":"3de64pub9jp00ujyzwfg3haf7","appversion":"1.0","deviceid":"mydevice","merchantid":"times_prime"}

3.  use above token as auth_token to gain target user' info.
eg: 
https://tpstage.timesprime.com/payment/payments/web/v4/getpaymentdetails?devicetype=web

title: Wordpress wp-config Backup File Exposed
extra_info: it was observed that the application having a backup of the wp-config.php file which is exposed publicly. this backup file contains information about the database, including the name, host (typically localhost), username, and password.
it is recommended to restrict access to this file or remove it from the website.
- go to the following url "https://stgweb65.etmoney.tech/blog/.wp-config.php.swp" and we can see that the application is disclosing a wp-config backup file.

title: Blind Stored XSS - Admin panel
extra_info:
it was observed that the application is not validating user-submitted data while completing the account setup (where the user required to submit his/her personal details). a user can submit any malicious javascript payload in the mothername parameter which will lead to a blind stored xss attack in the admin dashboard. by successfully exploiting this issue an attacker is able to access critical information from the admin panel. the xss reveals the administrator’s ip address, backend application service, admin session cookies etc.

- vulnerable url: https://stgpartner66.etmoney.tech/api/users/user-investments/update-iaof
- vulnerable parameter: mothername
- javascript execution point (admin dashboard): https://172.29.46.94/admin/manageinvestoriaof
note: the recommendation needs to be applied though out the application.

- login to the application with a user account and go to insurance->fixed deposit
- now select any plan and click on continue to deposit
- for deposit, a user needs to complete his/her account setup by submitting their personal details which will be verified by the backend/admin team. while doing this process there is an option for submitting the mother's name.
- now this mothername parameter is not validating user-submitted data, a user can submit any malicious javascript payload in the input and submit that data. refer to attached screenshot- vulnerable-request.png

title: Lack of Rate-Limiting- OTP Bombing
extra_info: rate limiting is used to control the rate of traffic sent or received by a network interface controller and is used to prevent dos attacks.

it was observed that the "verify details" functionality lacks rate-limiting due to which it was possible to target a user to receive a large number of otp sms from et money.

vulnerable url: https://stgpartner66.etmoney.tech/api/ca-insurance/send-otp

it is recommended to implement rate-limiting on the affected functionality (suggested value is five) after which the user's request should be disregarded and not allowed to perform further submissions. server-side validations should be implemented to ensure a brute-force attack cannot be performed.

- note: the recommendation needs to be applied though out the application.

- login to the application with a user account and go to insurance->term life ensure and click on buy
- when a user clicks on buy that user needs to fill in his/her details and in the next step, user need to verify a mobile number 
- now this mobile verification api has a rate limit issue due to which a user can send multiple sms to any user by changing the deviceid value parameter value.
 
impact: an unauthenticated user can utilize the "send otp" functionality to send a large number of otps to a mobile number which can lead to reputational damage. depending upon the sms gateway being used it might also cause a financial loss due to a large number of sms deliveries being performed.

title: HTML Injection
extra_info: html injection is an attack that is similar to cross-site scripting (xss). while in the xss vulnerability the attacker can inject and execute javascript code, the html injection attack only allows the injection of certain html tags. when an application does not properly handle user supplied data, an attacker can supply valid html code, typically via a parameter value, and inject their own content into the page. this attack is typically used in conjunction with some form of social engineering, as the attack is exploiting a code-based vulnerability and a user's trust

impact:- this vulnerability can have many consequences, like disclosure of a user's session
cookies that could be used to impersonate the victim, or, more generally, it can allow the
attacker to modify the page content seen by the victims.

mitigation : script should filter metacharacters from user input.

there are no doubts, that the main reason for this attack is the developer’s inattention and lack of knowledge. this type of injection attack occurs when the input and output are not properly validated. therefore the main rule to prevent html attack is appropriate data validation.

every input should be checked if it contains any script code or any html code. usually it is being checked, if the code contains any special script or html brackets – , .

there are many functions for checking if the code contains any special brackets. selection of checking function depends on the programming language, that you are using.
steps_to_reproduce: refer poc

title: HTML Injection
extra_info: html injection is an attack that is similar to cross-site scripting (xss). while in the xss vulnerability the attacker can inject and execute javascript code, the html injection attack only allows the injection of certain html tags. when an application does not properly handle user supplied data, an attacker can supply valid html code, typically via a parameter value, and inject their own content into the page. this attack is typically used in conjunction with some form of social engineering, as the attack is exploiting a code-based vulnerability and a user's trust

impact:- this vulnerability can have many consequences, like disclosure of a user's session
cookies that could be used to impersonate the victim, or, more generally, it can allow the
attacker to modify the page content seen by the victims.

mitigation : script should filter metacharacters from user input.

html injection uses html to deface the page. xss, as the name implies, injects javascript into the page. both attacks exploit insufficient validation of user input.

a simple example of potential html injection is an application’s “search” form, in which the user enters a query text. when the user submits the query, the application responds by dynamically generating a web page that shows matching results. this results page often shows the original query text to let the user see the context of these results. if the embedded query text contains syntactically correct html, it may add attacker-controlled text, images and links to this generated response page

there are no doubts, that the main reason for this attack is the developer’s inattention and lack of knowledge. this type of injection attack occurs when the input and output are not properly validated. therefore the main rule to prevent html attack is appropriate data validation.
your script should filter metacharacters from user input.
refer poc

every input should be checked if it contains any script code or any html code. usually it is being checked, if the code contains any special script or html brackets – , .

there are many functions for checking if the code contains any special brackets. selection of checking function depends on the programming language, that you are using.
steps_to_reproduce: refer poc

title: Link Injection
extra_info:
link manipulation occurs when an application embeds user input into the path or domain of urls that appear within application responses. an attacker can use this vulnerability to construct a link that, if visited by another application user, will modify the target of urls within the response. it may be possible to leverage this to perform various attacks, such as:
manipulating the path of an on-site link that has sensitive parameters in the url. if the response from the modified path contains references to off-site resources, then the sensitive data might be leaked to external domains via the referer header.
manipulating the url targeted by a form action, making the form submission have unintended side effects.
manipulating the url used by a css import statement to point to an attacker-uploaded file, resulting in css injection.
injecting on-site links containing xss exploits, thereby bypassing browser anti-xss defenses, since those defenses typically do not operate on on-site links.
the security impact of this issue depends largely on the nature of the application functionality. even if it has no direct impact on its own, an attacker may use it in conjunction with other vulnerabilities to escalate their overall severity.
consider using a whitelist to restrict user input to safe values. please note that in some situations this issue will have no security impact, meaning no remediation is necessary.

title: Insecure Data Storage
extra_info:
during the assessment, it was observed that the application storing user’s data such as username, mobile no, session tokens etc in the shared preference without having proper encryption.
- file: data/data/com.stage.longwalks.android/shared_prefs/longwalks_prefs.cnf.xml

note: the vulnerability was observed on the reported instances. however, the recommendation needs to be applied to the entire application.
it is recommended to not store any sensitive data in the shared preference such as username name, passwords, token, etc. if required, then proper cryptography control should be used.
mitigation: it is recommended to not store any sensitive data in the shared preference such as username name, passwords, token, etc. if required, then proper cryptography control should be used.

title: URL Injection
extra_info: url injection is when a malicious individual attacks your website through the insertion of dangerous code that makes it appear as though your website gives credit to a detrimental site.

it was observed that the application is vulnerable to url injection attacks. as the application is not validating user-submitted data a user can add any url in the profile image.
vulnerable url: https://api-staging.longwalks.com/v1/auth/updateuser
vulnerable parameter: profileimageurl
it is recommended to use a whitelist of allowed domains and protocols from where the web server can fetch remote resources.

- login to the application with the user and go to edit profile->change profile photo
- select any photo from your device and click on upload
- now click on the save button and capture that request. refer to attached poc- original-api-request.png
- in the captured request change the profileimageurl value with any other website url such as evil.com etc. refer to attached poc- modified-api-request.png

as the url has been successfully submitted in the user profile now whenever some other users in the application visit our profile they will unintentionally hit our submitted url which might lead to ddos attack.

title: Business Logic (User Account Delete)
extra_info: it was observed that the application does not have any server side controls to identify whether the account deletion request is valid or not.

it is recommended to have proper server side controls for deleting an account. ex: whenever users hit the delete button an api call should be initiated which will tell the backend server that a particular user has initiated a delete account request.

- login to the application with a user account and go to edit profile and click on delete account. refer to attached poc: delete-account-png
- after click on delete account application redirects to email options with the user details such as user id which will need to be sent to support@longwalks.com for deleting the account. refer to attached poc- delete-account-details.png
- now if a user will change his/her user id with another user account and sent that email to the support team. it might lead to unauthorized deletion of any user accounts in the application 

note: for getting another users id just go to search people and the backend api (https://api-staging.longwalks.com/v1/auth/searchusers?user_id=-mv_efoqd8xyxkc7c0kl&keyword=test) will disclose all the user's id in the response. refer to attached poc: search-user-id.png

title: Directory listing
extra_info:
configure your web server to prevent directory listings for all paths beneath the web root;
place into each directory a default file (such as index.htm) that the web server will display instead of returning a directory listing.
steps_to_reproduce: https://crm.dineout.co.in/icons/
mitigation:
configure your web server to prevent directory listings for all paths beneath the web root;
place into each directory a default file (such as index.htm) that the web server will display instead of returning a directory listing.

extra_info: in this application there is an offer through which users can validate hdfc cards with 1 re flow and according to the type of the card they will get the offer.(like 2.5% off to 15%off) and the dineout passport membership. so internally as discussed with @chhavi garg that this will be done through some bin no. that are saved internally at db. but here i have successfully accessed all the bin no. corresponding to the offers. and used that to convert my regalia card to corporate card and successfully got all the offers of the corporate card.

1. sensitive  bin no. list should not be publicly exposed.
 2. while validating the card the bin no. should be matched with the original payment 
 card, so if someone changes the bin no. then the transaction should be declined.

step1:-first i got all the exposed bin no. using the post request (post /get_payment_option).
step2:- now i have taken one random bin no. from the exposed list (45726212) which is supposed to be a corporate credit card.
step3:- now go to card offer details and click on edit card and fill the card details and capture this request via proxy.
step4:- now change the bin no. of the original card to the one we got from the exposed list of bin no.
step5:- now go to the payment page and complete the re1 transaction. my regalia card has now changed to corporate card and i got all the privileges of corporate card (dineout passport membership for 1 year of all cities).

3. validate card for offer after successfully completing the re1 transaction.

step1:-first i got all the exposed bin no. using the post request (post /get_payment_option).
step2:- now i have taken one random bin no. from the exposed list (45726212) which is supposed to be a corporate credit card.
step3:- now go to card offer details and click on edit card and fill the card details and capture this request via proxy.
step4:- now change the bin no. of the original card to the one we got from the exposed list of bin no.
step5:- now go to the payment page and complete the re1 transaction. my regalia card has now changed to corporate card and i got all the privileges of corporate card (dineout passport membership for 1 year of all cities).

in this vulnerability, i exploited the top up mycash functionality. usually in a normal scenario a user clicks on the top up mycash and adds money and pays using the preferred payment method. but here i used mycash itself to add mycash and got the extra 5% promocash, percentage of which can be used to pay restaurants bills every time. each time i have to add re 1 more than the amount that i have in mycash and just only have to pay re1 to add money. and due to this each time i'll get extra 5% promocash by just only making a transaction of re1.
impact:-  financial impact as by only making re1 transactions for multiple times i can get extra 5% promo cash(this is 10% on production) multiple times.
mitigation:- the parameter is_do_wallet_used should not be used for adding mycash transactions.

step1:-  go to top up mycash section. as i have rs 682 in my wallet so i tried to add rs 683(re 1 extra than existing amount) in mycash wallet.
step2:-  click on proceed to add rs 683 and capture this request via proxy.
step3:-  now change the form is_do_wallet_used=0 to is_do_wallet_used=1.
step4:-  do this repeatedly on the next two requests.
step5:-  as i already have rs 682, so now i have to pay only re 1(rs 683-rs 682=re1). by successfully tampering the parameter is_do_wallet_used i have used the existing mycash amount to add mycash and each time availing the 5% extra promo cash(in this case rs 35).

in this vulnerability i exploited the valid flow of purchasing the girf deal and events ticket. by exploiting this i am able to purchase girf deal for 10 guests at the cost of 1. in the same way i can buy 10 event tickets at the cost of 1 guest entry.

i noticed that the two different parameters are used for booking deals cnt_covers and quantity. it is recommended to use one parameter or should check this at the server side in case of parameter tampering. should reject such transactions. 
in short, the keys to preventing business logic vulnerabilities are to: 
make sure developers and testers understand the domain that the application serves. 
avoid making implicit assumptions about user behavior or the behavior of other parts of the application.

step1:- go to girf deal section and add 10 guests to purchase deal. now click on confirm to complete the purchase(capture this request via proxy).
step2:- now send this captured request to the proxy and release the captured request.
step3:- now at repeater change 'quantity' parameter for 10 to 1.
step4:- now before clicking on pay, send the same request that we captured at proxy via repeater with the modified 'quantity' parameter. 
step5:- now at the payment page the amount is reduced to 1 guest. complete the payment and the booking for 10 guests is confirmed at the cost of 1.
step6:- successfully redeem the deal.

in this vulnerability we exploited the tip parameter for reducing the bill amount. as there is no validation and check at server side it is possible to change the tip value to negative amount and it get processed and subtracts from the final total amount.
do not take the negative tip value and check it at server side and throw an error.

step1:- click on tip amount and capture the request via proxy.
step2:- now change it to negative value and forward the request. now click on pay and similarly change the tip value to negative.
step3:- finally the negative tip is processed and it got subtracted from the final amount.

it is possible to freeze out all existing deal. initiate a valid deal purchase transaction and choose 10 girf tickets to buy and now choose intermiles as payment method but at the final stage cancel the transaction. now the payment goes to pending state(as discussed with sanket) and remains pending(should change to failed ). but all the 10 deals got freezed and now are unavailable for other valid customers.
impact:- possible to make girf deal offer dysfunctional as if malicious user do this to all the deals then all those get freezed.
after 5 to 10 min change the payment status to failed or unlock the deals for other users to purchase.

title: Sensitive Information running on HTTP
extra_info:
complete or few parts of application  transmits sensitive critical data in cleartext in an unencrypted http communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.
many communication channels can be "sniffed" by attackers during data transmission. for example, network traffic can often be sniffed by any attacker who has access to a network interface. this significantly lowers the difficulty of exploitation by attackers.
it was observed that in-scope application were communicating over the unencrypted channel which might lead to the disclosure of sensitive information such as username, password, etc.

encrypt the data with a reliable encryption scheme before transmitting.
when using web/mobile applications with ssl, use ssl for the entire session from login to logout, not just for the initial login page.
use tls 1.2
- go to the application url "http://54.145.204.207:4300/"and we can see application is running over http
steps_to_reproduce: - go to the application url "http://54.145.204.207:4300/"and we can see application is running over http

title: Lack of Rate-Limiting- Email Bombing
extra_info: rate limiting is used to control the rate of traffic sent or received by a network interface controller and is used to prevent dos attacks.

it was observed that the "forget password" functionality lacks rate-limiting due to which it was possible to target a user to receive a large number of emails.
- vulnerable url: http://54.145.204.207:9008/times/concierge/password/forget

it is recommended to implement rate-limiting on the affected functionality (suggested value is three) after which the user's request should be disregarded and not allowed to perform further submissions. server-side validations should be implemented to ensure a brute-force attack cannot be performed.

- go to the forget password and enter any email address and click on the send button
- now repeat the same step, again and again, we can see user email address get full with our password reset emails.

title: SSRF
extra_info:
a successful ssrf attack can often result in unauthorized actions or access to data within the organization, either in the vulnerable application itself or on other back-end systems that the application can communicate with. in some situations, the ssrf vulnerability might allow an attacker to perform arbitrary command execution.

an ssrf exploit that causes connections to external third-party systems might result in malicious onward attacks that appear to originate from the organization hosting the vulnerable application, leading to potential legal liabilities and reputational damage.

it was observed that forget password functionality is vulnerable to ssrf attack.
- vulnerable url: http://54.145.204.207:9008/times/concierge/password/forget
it is recommended to implement a whitelist of permitted services and hosts and block any interactions that do not appear on this whitelist.

title: Malicious File Upload
extra_info:
uploaded files represent a significant risk to applications. the first step in many attacks is to get some code to the system to be attacked. then the attack only needs to find a way to get the code executed. using a file upload helps the attacker accomplish the first step.

the consequences of unrestricted file upload can vary, including complete system takeover, an overloaded file system or database, forwarding attacks to back-end systems, client-side attacks, or simple defacement. it depends on what the application does with the uploaded file and especially where it is stored.
it was observed that the application was vulnerable to malicious file upload where a user can easily upload a file containing malicious content such as .html,exe file, etc.

it is recommended to create a whitelist of all the allowed file extensions to be uploaded to the server and no other file type should be allowed to get uploaded. executable files such as .exe, .php, etc. must be blocked, also use special checks at every multimedia input fields to check for validation.

following solutions are recommended to fix unrestricted file upload:
i) application should check allowed file extension and file type (mime type) in the upload module using white list filter at sever side.
ii) file to be uploaded should be restricted to a particular size.
iii) server side check for not allowing long filename with double extension / double dot(.) / nullbyte (%00)/meta characters.
iv) assign only read and write permissions to be upload folders are required.
v) content parsing should be done properly after sanitizing blacklisted characters.

note: the above-mentioned recommendation should be implemented throughout the application in upload functionality.

- login to the application with an admin account and go to manage activity
- in the manage activity click on the edit button. refer to the attached screenshot- malicious-fileupload-1.png
- after clicking on the edit button a user can change the content and upload any image. refer to the attached screenshot- malicious-fileupload-1.2.png
- now select any malicious file in uploadimage ex:.html or exe and click on the submit button.
- after submission, we can see our submitted file has been successfully uploaded. uploaded file url "https://test-img.timespoints.com/static/images/test.html". refer to the attached screenshot- malicious-fileupload-1.3.png

title: Lack or Misconfiguration of Security Headers
description: Lack or Misconfiguration of Security Headers
extra_info: http security headers are a subset of http headers and are exchanged between a web client (usually a browser) and a server to specify the security-related details of http communication. some http headers that are indirectly related to privacy and security can also be considered http security headers.

it was observed that, for the website, key security http headers such as content-security-policy, x-content-type-options and referrer-policy were not configured. also, the value of the x-frame-options header is not configured properly.

it is recommended to set security http headers as per the best security policy.

refer: https://www.netsparker.com/blog/web-security/http-security-headers/

note: the recommendation needs to be applied throughout the applications.

- go to the application url "http://test.timespoints.com/" and "http://test.ngage.timespoints.com/" and check for the response.
- in the response, we can see the application does not have proper security headers.

title: OS Command Injection
steps_to_reproduce: step 1:step 2:step 3:......

extra_info: here, we can exploit the credit card offer flow by making payment with any card, i.e we actually don't need hdfc card to avail this offer. we can avail it by paying with any other card by changing the first 6 digit of card(refer steps to produce and poc for more details).
post transaction verify the bin with actual card used for payment. in case of mismatch cancel the transaction and initiate refund.

step1:- i have selected my icici debit card for payment and captured this request via proxy.
step2:- now, i have changed the first 6 digit of my icici card with my hdfc credit card and successfully availed the discount offer on hdfc card. 
step3:- and now i can finally pay it using my icici debit card.

step1:- go to dineout passport membership and select ahmedabad pack worth rs 449(after discount rs359) and click on buy now.
step2:- as i have rs 551 in wallet so i have to click on pay to complete the transaction. but i captured this request via proxy after clicking on pay.
step3:- now send this captured request to the repeater of the proxy.
step4:- now drop this captured request on interceptor.
step5:- now on android app initiate a new transaction in the same way but this time for dineout passport pune pack worth rs 449(after discount rs359).
step6:- now click on buy now and after this final pay option will come. now hold.

title: HTML Injection
extra_info: html injection is an attack that is similar to cross-site scripting (xss). while in the xss vulnerability the attacker can inject and execute javascript code, the html injection attack only allows the injection of certain html tags. when an application does not properly handle user supplied data, an attacker can supply valid html code, typically via a parameter value, and inject their own content into the page. this attack is typically used in conjunction with some form of social engineering, as the attack is exploiting a code-based vulnerability and a user's trust

impact:- this vulnerability can have many consequences, like disclosure of a user's session
cookies that could be used to impersonate the victim, or, more generally, it can allow the
attacker to modify the page content seen by the victims.

mitigation : script should filter metacharacters from user input.

impact:- this vulnerability can have many consequences, like disclosure of a user's session

title: Information Disclosure
extra_info: it was observed that the application is disclosing the author's mail address in the source. email addresses of developers and other individuals (whether appearing on-screen or hidden within page source) may disclose information that is useful to an attacker; for example, they may represent usernames that can be used at the application's login, and they may be used in social engineering attacks against the organization's personnel. unnecessary or excessive disclosure of email addresses may also lead to an increase in the volume of spam email received.
it is recommended to remove any email addresses that are unnecessary or replacing personal addresses with anonymous mailbox addresses (such as helpdesk@example.com).

title: Sensitive Information running on HTTP
extra_info:
complete or few parts of application  transmits sensitive critical data in cleartext in an unencrypted http communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.
many communication channels can be "sniffed" by attackers during data transmission. for example, network traffic can often be sniffed by any attacker who has access to a network interface. this significantly lowers the difficulty of exploitation by attackers.
it was observed that in-scope application were communicating over the unencrypted channel which might lead to the disclosure of sensitive information such as username, password, etc.

encrypt the data with a reliable encryption scheme before transmitting.
when using web/mobile applications with ssl, use ssl for the entire session from login to logout, not just for the initial login page.
use tls 1.2
go to the application url http://staging.whatshot.in and we can see the application is running over http.
steps_to_reproduce: go to the application url http://staging.whatshot.in and we can see the application is running over http.

title: Horizontal Privilege Escalation
extra_info:
it was observed that the application had weak access control restrictions. it was possible for a "low privilege" user to access the functionalities/url of the "high privileged" user. low privilege users were able to access the content of high privilege users through forced browsing.

note: the reported issue needs to be fixed throughout the application.

vulnerable urls:
- call center: https://staging.dineout.co.in/admin/admin/call_center
- party module: https://staging.dineout.co.in/admin/party/party_list/

it is recommended that the application should have a robust authorization mechanism wherein the privileges of logged-in user (whose identity is verified using the session id) are checked at the server end prior to granting access to privileged functionalities. once the user’s identity is verified, it must be determined whether that user has access to the requested resource. there are several approaches to a role‐based authorization which could be used, like
1) url authorization - using whitelists to specify which pages or functions or urls are allowed for which users
2) explicit role checks - checking what role each user has, and granting them access to the particular functions or urls available to that role only.

reference:- https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/owasp_top_ten_2017/top_10-2017_a5-broken_access_control

- login to the application with an admin user account "admin@dineout.co.in" in the other browser login with normal user account "pankaj.yadav1@dineout.in"
- in the normal user account dashboard, we can see the user does not have access to call center and party module.
- but by doing the force browsing/copying url user can access both the modules. 

vulnerable urls:
- call center: https://staging.dineout.co.in/admin/admin/call_center
- party module: https://staging.dineout.co.in/admin/party/party_list/
steps_to_reproduce:
- login to the application with an admin user account "admin@dineout.co.in" in the other browser login with normal user account "pankaj.yadav1@dineout.in"
- in the normal user account dashboard, we can see the user does not have access to call center and party module.
- but by doing the force browsing/copying url user can access both the modules. 

vulnerable urls:
- call center: https://staging.dineout.co.in/admin/admin/call_center
- party module: https://staging.dineout.co.in/admin/party/party_list/
mitigation:
it is recommended that the application should have a robust authorization mechanism wherein the privileges of logged-in user (whose identity is verified using the session id) are checked at the server end prior to granting access to privileged functionalities. once the user’s identity is verified, it must be determined whether that user has access to the requested resource. there are several approaches to a role‐based authorization which could be used, like
1) url authorization - using whitelists to specify which pages or functions or urls are allowed for which users
2) explicit role checks - checking what role each user has, and granting them access to the particular functions or urls available to that role only.

reference:- https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/owasp_top_ten_2017/top_10-2017_a5-broken_access_control
