title: HTML Injection
extra_info: html injection is an attack that is similar to cross-site scripting (xss). while in the xss vulnerability the attacker can inject and execute javascript code, the html injection attack only allows the injection of certain html tags. when an application does not properly handle user-supplied data, an attacker can supply valid html code, typically via a parameter value, and inject their own content into the page. this attack is typically used in conjunction with some form of social engineering, as the attack is exploiting a code-based vulnerability and a user's trust

it was observed that the application is not validating user-submitted data in the url which leads to an html injection attack.

vulnerable url: https://staging.dineout.co.in/admin/booking/newbooking?booking_status=nw&tbl_alloc_status=&booking_type=&booking_display_id=&diner_name=&diner_email=&diner_phone=&rest_auto=&restaurant_id=&booking_start_date=&booking_end_date=&creation_date=&b_type=&d_type=&u_type=&tag=&is_pf=&affiliate_id=&tag=&sla=&area_id=&locality_id=

note: the reported issue needs to be fixed throughout the application.

it is recommended to implement html output encoding for all data obtained from external sources such as user input and database servers. further, ensure that the user-submitted data is properly validated using strong regular expressions so that invalid input cannot be submitted to the application.

- login to the application with a user account and go to bookings
- in bookings add any html tags in the user input parameter and click on search. refer to attached poc.

title: SSRF
extra_info:
a successful ssrf attack can often result in unauthorized actions or access to data within the organization, either in the vulnerable application itself or on other back-end systems that the application can communicate with. in some situations, the ssrf vulnerability might allow an attacker to perform arbitrary command execution.

an ssrf exploit that causes connections to external third-party systems might result in malicious onward attacks that appear to originate from the organization hosting the vulnerable application, leading to potential legal liabilities and reputational damage.

it was observed that while generating a qr code application does not have proper whitelisting of the domain name which allows a user to call any third-party resource interaction.

note: the reported issue needs to be fixed throughout the application.
it is recommended to implement a whitelist of permitted services and hosts and block any interactions that do not appear on this whitelist.

title: No Account Lockout
extra_info: it was observed that the server-side implementation for handling authenticated api calls lacked an account lockout policy. due to this, it was possible to perform brute-force on any registered user’s account. during testing, it was possible to submit 10 incorrect passwords (to any authenticated api call) followed by a successful authentication when the correct password was supplied. hence, confirming that no account lockout policy was implemented on the server-side.
it is recommended that the application should implement an account lockout policy. ensure that the application locks out a user’s account after 3-5 incorrect login attempts.

- go to the application login page and add any valid email id/username and capture that request in burp
- now in burp send the same to intruder and perform a brute force attack against the user password. refer attached poc

- now add any random username and check the response. by validating the application response an attacker can identify the valid username.

title: xmlrpc.php is enabled
extra_info: xml-rpc is a specification that enables communication between wordpress and other systems. it did this by standardizing those communications, using http as the transport mechanism and xml as the encoding mechanism.

it was observed that in scope application "https://staging.dineout.co.in/blog/xmlrpc.php" has the xmlrpc.php file enabled and could thus be potentially used for such an attack against other victim hosts. wordpress that has xmlrpc.php enabled for pingbacks, trackbacks, etc. can be made as a part of a huge botnet causing a major ddos.
if the xmlrpc.php file is not being used, it should be disabled and removed completely to avoid any potential risks. otherwise, it should at the very least be blocked from external access.

- go to the following url "https://staging.dineout.co.in/blog/xmlrpc.php" and capture that request in burp suite
- in burp suit change the request method to post. refer to attached poc.
- in the post request add the string tags to list down all the methods.refer to attached poc.
here an attacker can exploit this vulnerability to add unlimited balance to the account without need of any gift card.
never allow negative values in "quantity" parameter. check this at server side if someone manipulates it server should throw an error invalid request.

step1:- initially buy now button is disabled as i have 0 balance in my account.
step2:- so by manipulating response parameter "balance" to rs 10 the buy now button is now enabled.
step3:- but still i am unable to purchase any coupon as i don't have any actual points in my balance and after checking at server side it gives an error of insufficient balance.
step4:- but now i captured the buy now request (post /api/orders) and manipulated the value of parameter "quantity" to form 1 to -1 and forwarded this request.
step5:- the request get processed successfully and my order is successfully placed.
step6:- as my quantity is -1 , so my updated balance will be 0-(-10) = 10 and coupon is also generated at free of cost.
step7:- in the similar by manipulating this parameter an attacker can add as much balance.(refer poc).

an attacker can exploit this vulnerability to redeem same add balance gift card multiple times. here, by making simultaneous request with. same gift code or brute forcing the same request the same coupon will get redeemed multiple times as before updating the status for that code in database the new request is initiated. so, all these requests will get processed and the same coupon was redeemed multiple times.

step1:- click on add(+) gift code to add balance.
step2:- i have rs 50 gift code(dev5b4da2fb3fc69).
step3:- click on apply and capture this request via proxy.
step4:- now send this request. to burp intruder(used for brute force attacks).
step5:- now, i initiated brute force attack on this request with same gift code for 4 times.
step6:- previous balance was rs 250 and the updated balance = 450(250+4*50).
here an attacker can generate free coupons by manipulating the "quantity" parameter. it is also possible to purchase the out of stock coupon.

step1:- click on buy now and capture this request via proxy.
step2:- now manipulate the "quantity" parameter value to "0".
step3:- now forward this request, it will get processed and coupon code is successfully generated at 0 points(refer poc).

et is organizing etbrandequity spott awards 2021 | july 29, 2021. here candidates can register and start adding entries by selecting the categories. once candidates have added all entries they need to make the required payment. here, it is certainly possible for a malicious user to register for all the categories by bypassing the payment. here, i will demonstrate this critical issue by selecting 14 categories amounting to rs 2,31,280 (inc gst) and bypassing the payment to make it rs 1 for registering all these 14 categories.

when the product is added in the cart calculate hash for the total request and compare with the backend so that if any manipulation happens in the request for any value it is different from the server's hash. 
validate input for improper characters, values and data types. specifically for this case, must decline a transaction if someone tampers with the parameter by putting a proxy in between.

step1:- register on https://brandequity.economictimes.indiatimes.com/spott-awards/nomination?trk=1&ag=brandsolution_nav by clicking on nominate now.
step2:- after registration login to your account and select the categories in which you want to register. here, i have selected 14 categories amounting to rs 2,31,280 (inc gst).
step3:-  now, after proceeding with selections we have to select the categories for which we want to make the nomination by making payment. here, i selected 14 categories.
step4:- now click on pay now and capture this request via proxy.
step5:- now change the parameter variable_amount=231280 to variable_amount=1 and forward this request.
step6:-  now at the final payment page the final amount to be paid is rs 1. i have selected upi as payment mode for completing this transaction and successfully got the upi request of rs 1 on phonepe.

title: Blind Stored XSS - Admin panel
extra_info: it was observed that the application is not validating user-submitted data which leads to the admin account take over using blind xss.

- go to the feedback and submit any feedback. now, wait for an admin to add updates on the feedback.
- once the feedback status has been updated by the admin. a user can add their comment against the feedback. now the comment parameter is not validating user-submitted data which leads to xss in the admin account. please refer to the attached screenshot. blind xss_vulnerable parameter.png
- by successfully exploiting this issue we were able to fetch admin cookies. please refer to the attached screenshot: blind xss-1.png
- by using the admin cookies were able to completely take over the admin account. please refer to the attached screenshot: blind xss-admin-takeover.png

title: HTML Injection
extra_info: html injection is an attack that is similar to cross-site scripting (xss). while in the xss vulnerability the attacker can inject and execute javascript code, the html injection attack only allows the injection of certain html tags. when an application does not properly handle user supplied data, an attacker can supply valid html code, typically via a parameter value, and inject their own content into the page. this attack is typically used in conjunction with some form of social engineering, as the attack is exploiting a code-based vulnerability and a user's trust

impact:- this vulnerability can have many consequences, like disclosure of a user's session
cookies that could be used to impersonate the victim, or, more generally, it can allow the
attacker to modify the page content seen by the victims.

mitigation : script should filter metacharacters from user input.

title: Link Injection
extra_info: url injection is when a malicious individual attacks your website through the insertion of dangerous code that makes it appear as though your website gives credit to a detrimental site.

it was observed that the application is vulnerable to url injection attacks. as the application is not validating user-submitted data a user can add any url in the offer images.

vulnerable url: http://54.145.204.207:9007/times/cms/offers/save

note: the reported issue needs to be fixed throughout the application.
it is recommended to use a whitelist of allowed domains and protocols from where the webserver can fetch remote resources.

login to the application with the user and go to offers
select any offer and click on edit
now do some changes and click on the save button and capture that request. refer to attached poc- url injection-1.3.png
in the captured request change the logo/image value with any other website url such as evil.com etc. refer to attached poc- url injection-1.4.png
*as the url has been successfully submitted in the application now whenever any users in the application visit that offer page they will unintentionally hit our submitted url which might lead to a ddos attack.

title: Sensitive Information running on HTTP
extra_info:
complete or few parts of application  transmits sensitive critical data in cleartext in an unencrypted http communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.
many communication channels can be "sniffed" by attackers during data transmission. for example, network traffic can often be sniffed by any attacker who has access to a network interface. this significantly lowers the difficulty of exploitation by attackers.

description

it was observed that in-scope application were communicating over the unencrypted channel which might lead to the disclosure of sensitive information such as username, password, etc.

encrypt the data with a reliable encryption scheme before transmitting.
when using web/mobile applications with ssl, use ssl for the entire session from login to logout, not just for the initial login page.
use tls 1.2

steps to produce

go to the application url "http://54.145.204.207:4300/"and we can see application is running over http
steps_to_reproduce:
steps to produce

go to the application url "http://54.145.204.207:4300/"and we can see application is running over http

title: SSRF
extra_info:
a successful ssrf attack can often result in unauthorized actions or access to data within the organization, either in the vulnerable application itself or on other back-end systems that the application can communicate with. in some situations, the ssrf vulnerability might allow an attacker to perform arbitrary command execution.

an ssrf exploit that causes connections to external third-party systems might result in malicious onward attacks that appear to originate from the organization hosting the vulnerable application, leading to potential legal liabilities and reputational damage.

it was observed that forget password functionality is vulnerable to ssrf attack.

vulnerable url: http://54.145.204.207:9007/times/cms/password/forget
it is recommended to implement a whitelist of permitted services and hosts and block any interactions that do not appear on this whitelist.

go to the forget password functionality and submit any email address and intercept that request
in the intercepted request change the host value with any other domain (for testing we have replaced the host value to our burp collaborator) and forward that request. refer to the attached screenshot- ssrf-1.1.png and ssrf-1.2.png
now wait for some time and we can see that the application is interacting with our supplied host url. refer to the attached screenshot- ssrf-poc.png.

title: Payment Bypass (By ParameterTampering )
extra_info: here, it is possible for an user to tamper the response of the fetchtaxeligibility request to remove the mandatory 18% gst amount from the transaction.

1:- do not rely on client side validations.
2:- should be checked at server side.

step1:- go to create new campaign and choose objective(here i have chosen brand awareness).
step2:- fill all the details and click on target your ad.
step3:- now fill the details and click on pay and go live and capture all the requests and responses via proxy.
step4:- now tamper the response parameter "applytax": true to "applytax": false of the post request(post /expresso/selfservice/fetchtaxelibility.htm).
step5:- now fill all the billing information and make the final payment of rs 10500(18% gst not included) instead of rs 12390(18% gst inclusive).
step6:- your purchase will get successfully completed.
steps_to_reproduce:
step1:- go to create new campaign and choose objective(here i have chosen brand awareness).
step2:- fill all the details and click on target your ad.
step3:- now fill the details and click on pay and go live and capture all the requests and responses via proxy.
step4:- now tamper the response parameter "applytax": true to "applytax": false of the post request(post /expresso/selfservice/fetchtaxelibility.htm).
step5:- now fill all the billing information and make the final payment of rs 10500(18% gst not included) instead of rs 12390(18% gst inclusive).
step6:- your purchase will get successfully completed.
mitigation:
1:- do not rely on client side validations.
2:- should be checked at server side.

title: Stored XSS via crafted SVG file
description: Stored XSS via crafted SVG file
extra_info:
it was observed that the application is not validating user-submitted svg files which leads to a stored xss attack. by successfully exploiting this issue an attacker can send the malicious uploaded file url to victims and steals the victim's cookie leads to account takeover.

vulnerable request : https://qc9denmark.timesinternet.in/cmslite/api/upload/file

it is recommended to block svg files or sanitize files before upload.

note: the recommendation needs to be applied though out the application.

login to the application with a user account and go to any article and click on image upload
in the image upload application allows users to upload any svg file. so we have crafted a malicious svg file that will execute our javascript payload.
after upload check for the uploaded svg file "https://qc9denmark.timesinternet.in/cmslite/api/app/images.jpg?tempmediaid=43525". in the uploaded file we can see our submitted javascript payload has been successfully executed. kindly refer to the attached pocs for better understanding.

title: SSRF
extra_info:
a successful ssrf attack can often result in unauthorized actions or access to data within the organization, either in the vulnerable application itself or on other back-end systems that the application can communicate with. in some situations, the ssrf vulnerability might allow an attacker to perform arbitrary command execution.

an ssrf exploit that causes connections to external third-party systems might result in malicious onward attacks that appear to originate from the organization hosting the vulnerable application, leading to potential legal liabilities and reputational damage.

it was observed application does not have a whitelist of permitted services and hosts while fetching images which allows an attacker to interact with any domains.

vulnerable url: https://qc9denmark.timesinternet.in/api/ext/imagereco/?url=

it is recommended to implement a whitelist of permitted services and hosts and block any interactions that do not appear on this whitelist.

note: the recommendation needs to be applied though out the application.

login to the application with a user account and go to the article
in the article go to add image->search. in search click on select image and intercept that request. refer to the attached screenshot- ssrf-1.png
in the intercepted request "https://qc9denmark.timesinternet.in/api/ext/imagereco/?url=https://qc9denmark.timesinternet.in/cmslite/api/app/images.jpg?wfid=92640" change the url value with any other domain (for testing we have replaced the url value to our burp collaborator) and forward that request. refer to the attached screenshot- ssrf-1.2.png and ssrf-1.3.png
now wait for some time and we can see that the application is interacting with our supplied url. refer to the attached screenshot- ssrf-1.3.png.

title: Broken Access Control
extra_info:
steps to produce

steps

login to the application with a user account and go to create new-> slideshow
in the slideshow go to embeds. in embeds, users can search for images/documents in the application server and embed them into their articles/slideshow.
search for any document in embed and intercept that request. in the intercepted request we can see the application is passing the cookie header in the request. refer to the attached screenshot: improper-acess-control-1.3.png
now from the intercepted request remove the cookie header and forward that request. in the response, we can see the application is sending complete data without any authentication. refer to the attached screenshot: improper-acess-control-1.4.png
steps_to_reproduce:
steps to produce

steps

login to the application with a user account and go to create new-> slideshow
in the slideshow go to embeds. in embeds, users can search for images/documents in the application server and embed them into their articles/slideshow.
search for any document in embed and intercept that request. in the intercepted request we can see the application is passing the cookie header in the request. refer to the attached screenshot: improper-acess-control-1.3.png
now from the intercepted request remove the cookie header and forward that request. in the response, we can see the application is sending complete data without any authentication. refer to the attached screenshot: improper-acess-control-1.4.png

title: Information Disclosure

description

during the assessment, it was discovered that the some of the api in application displays the server version in the http response headers.

vulnerable url :
https://qc9denmark.timesinternet.in/api/ext/ibeatread/article-info?articleids=
https://qc9denmark.timesinternet.in/api/ext/search/solr/cms/suggest?fl=

server: apache/2.4.6 (centos) openssl/1.0.2k-fips

server: apache-coyote/1.1

mitigation

it is recommended to remove the http headers which include server configuration and type information, increasing overall website security.

note: the recommendation needs to be applied though out the application.

in the intercepted request some of the api is disclosing server version in the response. ex: https://qc9denmark.timesinternet.in/api/ext/ibeatread/article-info?articleids=

title: Replay Attack
extra_info:
1. login to the application and go to "challenge" and start any new challange.
2. now go to discussion section and add any new comment and take this request to the interceptor tool such as burp.
3. now forward the intercepted request to the intruder and send the same request multiple times ~10
4. now refresh and check the comment page, multiple data will be flooded at the same time.
steps_to_reproduce:

2. now go to discussion section and add any new comment and take this request to the interceptor tool such as burp.
3. now forward the intercepted request to the intruder and send the same request multiple times ~10
4. now refresh and check the comment page, multiple data will be flooded at the same time.

3. now send the request to any automated tool such as intruder and send multiple request with random emails. shown in image tc-1.2

2. now intercept the request. as shown in image tc-1.1
3. now send the request to any automated tool such as intruder and send multiple request with random emails. shown in image tc-1.2
4. check the response and multiple account will be created.

title: Replay Attack - Referral Code
extra_info: it is possible to bruteforce referral code due to replay requests.

1. try to register new account to the application and enter the invalid referral code.
2. now use automated tools such as  intruder to bruteforce the code by make combinations of chars.
3, now check the length of response valid response will says captcha is valid
4. invalid response will say captcha is invalid.
5. using this attacker can guess all the valid captcha
steps_to_reproduce:
1. try to register new account to the application and enter the invalid referral code.
2. now use automated tools such as  intruder to bruteforce the code by make combinations of chars.
3, now check the length of response valid response will says captcha is valid
4. invalid response will say captcha is invalid.
5. using this attacker can guess all the valid captcha

title: Lack of Rate-Limiting- OTP Bombing
extra_info: attacker can send multiple otps to any number

rate limiting is a strategy for limiting network traffic. it puts a cap on how often someone can repeat an action within a certain timeframe – for instance, trying to log in to an account. rate limiting can help stop certain kinds of malicious bot activity. it can also reduce strain on web servers.

1. send the vulnerable api call multiple times
2. user will receive otp multiple times as shown

title: OTP Bypass using Response Manipulation
extra_info: user can change the response from "mobile_verification_otp_sent":true to false and bypass the otp verification

1. create the new account and application will send otp verification code.
2. change the "mobile_verification_otp_sent" from true to false
3. application will accept and let user login without otp verification

title: Weak Auth Logic
extra_info: authoraiztion token consists 3 parts and two of them are static md5 hashes which can be guessed or cracked.
implement proper hashing or encryption mechanism which attacker cant break.

1. login to the app
2. get the auth token such as: a2cdd86a458242d42a17c2bf4feff069:de56378a85c94ef8707e09f76a0f8adf:09721ab88e0a552087391be1ef0c6826
3. first part is md5 of userid and last has is md5 of keywork android
4. attacker just have to break the middle part to fail the auth mechanism

title: Sensitive Information Disclosure(SSO Id and Times Prime User Details of any user)
description: Sensitive Information Disclosure(SSO Id and Times Prime User Details of any user)
extra_info:
times card provides times prime membership benefits to its users. here, a malicious user can use this functionality to access sso ids and times prime details of any user by exploiting times prime vulnerable api(post /mw/concurrent/v2/getuserdetails?) and it can also activate the different memberships of other times prime users using(post /gw/nc/prime/prime/membership/activate?).
impact:
critical data exposure(sso ids and times prime user details).
activate memberships of any other times prime subscribed users.
authorization token should be validated against sso id of current logged in user.

step1:- login to your times card account.
step2:- now click on the times prime tab under membership benefits.
step3:- now click to avail any membership(for eg zee 5) and capture these requests via proxy.
step4:- capture post /mw/concurrent/v2/getuserdetails? api and here change the "mobile":"xxxxxxxxxx" parameter value to any other user mobile.
step5:- you can fetch the details of any user.
step6:- similarly by capturing (post /gw/nc/prime/prime/membership/activate?) we can activate memberships of any other times prime subscribed users without users approval.
steps_to_reproduce:
step1:- login to your times card account.
step2:- now click on the times prime tab under membership benefits.
step3:- now click to avail any membership(for eg zee 5) and capture these requests via proxy.
step4:- capture post /mw/concurrent/v2/getuserdetails? api and here change the "mobile":"xxxxxxxxxx" parameter value to any other user mobile.
step5:- you can fetch the details of any user.
step6:- similarly by capturing (post /gw/nc/prime/prime/membership/activate?) we can activate memberships of any other times prime subscribed users without users approval.
mitigation: authorization token should be validated against sso id of current logged in user.

title: Full Account Takeover
extra_info: attacker can takeover the account of any non-registered user without otp verification with the help of jwt token leaked by the api
implement api such a way to only work for desired user with proper access control.

1. check if user exists or not. in our case, user doesnot exist.
2. now as shown in screenshot, theres an post api which is publishing data without any verification to any number and returning jwt in return.
3. now change the original request with victim phone number.
4. send the request and check for the response. application response will return with jwt token.
5. use this token to login into app and hit any api on behalf of victim.
6. decoding jwt as base64 will also satisfy that the obtained jwt belongs to victim only.
steps_to_reproduce:
1. check if user exists or not. in our case, user doesnot exist.
2. now as shown in screenshot, theres an post api which is publishing data without any verification to any number and returning jwt in return.
3. now change the original request with victim phone number.
4. send the request and check for the response. application response will return with jwt token.
5. use this token to login into app and hit any api on behalf of victim.
6. decoding jwt as base64 will also satisfy that the obtained jwt belongs to victim only.
mitigation: implement api such a way to only work for desired user with proper access control.

extra_info:
case 1:

1. login to the application and leave it logged it.
2. wait for 1-2 days and application will not expire the token

case 2:
1. logout to the application and old jwt token will still be useable even after logout
steps_to_reproduce:
case 1:

1. login to the application and leave it logged it.
2. wait for 1-2 days and application will not expire the token

case 2:
1. logout to the application and old jwt token will still be useable even after logout

title: Unrestricted file upload
extra_info:
1. login to the application and try to upload business profile image as shown.
2. now try to upload html file with malicious contest such as xss payload.
3. once the upload is completed, open the uploaded s3 bucket url and payload will be executed.
4. this is a object upload feature so server side attacks such as shell injection wont be possible but client side attacks such as xss are still possible to reproduce.
steps_to_reproduce:
1. login to the application and try to upload business profile image as shown.
2. now try to upload html file with malicious contest such as xss payload.
3. once the upload is completed, open the uploaded s3 bucket url and payload will be executed.
4. this is a object upload feature so server side attacks such as shell injection wont be possible but client side attacks such as xss are still possible to reproduce.

here, it is possible for a malicious user to permanently remove linked mobile number which is not possible for normal user.

step1:- click on add mobile.
step2:- now click any arbitrary mobile no. and now refresh the page without entering otp.
step3:- now the mobile is added but not verified.
step4:- here, is an option to delete this mobile no. 
step5:- click on delete and capture this request via proxy.
step6:- now change in the captured request change the mobile no. with your primary mobile no. and forward this request.
step7:- now your linked primary mobile no. is deleted permanently and the account have no primary mobile.

title: Two Primary Emails for one account
description: Two Primary Emails for one account
extra_info: here, it is possible for a malicious user to make two emails primary for a single account.

step1:- click on add another email and enter the email and click on add button.
step2:- capture this request(post /sso/identity/ajax/addalternateemailwithticket) via proxy.
step3:- now here change the parameter value (primaryemail=false to primaryemail=true).
step4:- now the other email will also be added as primary mail(i.e single account will have two primary emails).

here we have initiated the fixed deposit transaction of rs 50,000 and before making the payment we have tampered the request and changed the amount to rs 500 and then completed the transaction. after that the transaction goes into the pending state. then we waited for a few days to check the refund initiation process and we found that instead of a rs 500 refund we got a full refund of rs 50,000. we got this information via email. initially i am unable to capture those tampered requests and now the application is not working properly. so, with this email i am attaching the screenshot of the refund amount. for full poc i need a fully functional pre prod application.
server side validation if someone tampers amount.

step2:- capture the requests via proxy and tamper the amount with rs500.
step3:- now the transaction goes into pending state.
step4:- now after 4 - 5 days you will get the refund confirmation of full rs 50,000 amount.

title: Vulnerable and Outdated Components
extra_info:
the library jquery version 1.12.4 has known security issues. for more information, visit those websites:
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2432
http://blog.jquery.com/2016/01/08/jquery-2-2-and-1-12-released/
https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/cve-2015-9251
http://research.insecurelabs.org/jquery/test/

affected versions 
the vulnerability is affecting all versions prior 3.0.0-beta1 (between 1.12.3 and 3.0.0-beta1)
other considerations 
the vulnerability might be affecting a feature of the library that the website is not using. if the vulnerable feature is not used, this alert can be considered false positive.
the library name and its version are identified based on a retire.js signature. if the library identification is not correct, the prior vulnerability does not apply.
check the version of following file: https://dev.timesclub.co/js/jquery.min.js
steps_to_reproduce: check the version of following file: https://dev.timesclub.co/js/jquery.min.js

extra_info:
1. try to send the request with wrong username.
2. not send the request with correct username and right password.
3. compare the response. both are different user response. and attacker can use this to guess username

it is possible for an attacker to bypass the subscription check in application by modifying the application response. application is validate the server response client side which allow and attacker to avail the premium features without even having subscription.
do not rely on the client side response. validate the user access through server side or using jwt instead of relying on server response.

1. try to login to the app with free user.
2. intercept the following request "/prime-auth/android/prime/status?rspbody=true&clearcache=true"
3. now wait the for the application response the replace the response params as below:

"planstatus":5,"pendingsubs":false,"startdate":"fri, 29 oct 2021 14:42:10 ist","startdatems":1635498730000,"enddate":"fri, 28 oct 2022 23:58:59 ist","enddatems":1666981739000,"itunesftused":false,"source":"tp","accesstype":"timesprime","graceperiod":0,"renewnudgeperiod":0,"displayrenewnudge":false,"fromcache":true,"valid":true,"ingraceperiod":false

4. now forward the response and wait for the application to load the content. 
5. once done, check the subscription status and you will also able to read toi+ articles.

note: attacker can also use burp's match & replace to automated this process and use application in realtime.

title: Replay Attack
extra_info: attacker can earn reading times points without even reading the blog by just sending the api request multiple times.

1. try to read any toi+ article and intercept the request.
2. now take the following request: "/timespoint/submit/activity/toi?fv=870 "
3. send the multiple request by just modifying the "txnid" with some random numbers such as 92837483, 92837484, 92837485 so on.
4. check the points and they will be updated by 20 points per request.
steps_to_reproduce:
1. try to read any toi+ article and intercept the request.
2. now take the following request: "/timespoint/submit/activity/toi?fv=870 "
3. send the multiple request by just modifying the "txnid" with some random numbers such as 92837483, 92837484, 92837485 so on.
4. check the points and they will be updated by 20 points per request.

here, the minimum and maximum amount for easypay account activation is rs 500 and rs 99,999 respectively which can be tampered by intercepting the request via proxy and can be change to any desired amount. here, we have activated it with rs 5.

step1:- go to easypay and click on register easypay.
step2:- now, fill all the details. at the client side we cannot fill the amount less than rs 500. now after filling all the details click on continue and capture this request via proxy.
step3:- now tamper the request(post /api/users/user-investments/emandate-registration) parameter "emandateamountinpaise=50000" to "emandateamountinpaise=500" and forward the request and complete this registration by login to your net banking of respective registered bank account.
step4:- easypay is activated with limit of rs 5.

title: BLF-Weak Session Cookie Logic
extra_info: it is poosible for attacker to decrypt the 2 parts of cookie out of 3.
implement the more secure session or jwt.

1. login to the app and copy the session cookie.
2. as followed: 40f6e633518b32939156a842c93a84be:4de0d2972372253ac65e03f829bdeab4:ba3f2adea47b86b0d408de3f7e4d922c
3. cookie is in 3 parts separated by colon.
4. first part is md5 hash of userid.
5. last part is md5 hash of device type. (ios or android) 
6. middle part is generated by securerandom.
7. this way attacher can dehash the 1st and last part of cookie.

title: Unrestricted file upload
extra_info:
step-1 :  dropped a valid allowed file in applications file upload box (a pdf file)
step-2 :  intercepted the request while upload functionality
step-3 :  changed the extension of file from pdf to php and contents of file pdf file to a php code
step-4 :  forwarded the request and file is uploaded and got a json response message of success and file name of php file
step-5 :  click on download file and we get the path - https://staging.techgig.com/zs/files/saas/users/1668452871_test.php
step-6 :  file contents won't be shown or executed due to content-type: text/html; charset=utf-8 if above path is visited 
step-7 :  though , we can run the file programmatically depending on the code in the file and executed os level commands leading to various 
               category of attacks ssrf , fetching system files like /etc/passwd /etc/group /etc/shadow also all files residing under present directory which 
               allow us to download those files as well leading to critical information disclosure
step-8 :  we were able to bypass file size restriction and uploaded files of size more than 200 mb by changing client side set limit to any value while in intercept response which can be exploited and can result in server unavailability if files of any size can be upload
step-9 : it was noticed that download path was accessible even before user authenticates himself with form-based authentication which might result in any file access of any user with just http authentication .
step-10 :   poc can be found under proof of concept tab

it is common to see customized client-side input validation implemented within scripts. client-side controls of this kind are usually easy to circumvent; it is possible to enter a benign value into the input field in the browser, intercept the validated submission with your proxy, and modify the data to your desired value. this article details this method.

it is common to see customized client-side input validation implemented within scripts. client-side controls of this kind are usually easy to circumvent; it is possible to enter a benign value into the input field in the browser, intercept the validated submission with your proxy, and modify the data to your desired value. this article details this method.

note: client-side javascript routines to validate user input are common in web applications, but it should not be concluded that every such application is vulnerable. the application is exposed only if client-side validation is not replicated on the server, and even then only if crafted input that circumvents client-side validation can be used to cause some undesirable behavior by the application

always use server-side validation to protect your application from malicious attacks.

use the following steps when developing client side validation:

never trust the browser. because the browser is running on the user's machine, it can be fully controlled by the user. therefore, any client-side validation code can be controlled and bypassed by an attacker.

use javascript only to enhance your pages. javascript is useful for enhancing your application's presentation. however, it has no mechanism to protect the integrity of its code. do not rely on javascript to enforce security decisions.

place a server-side validator for all input. input validation should be executed on the server side. use the following steps to properly set the validation routines:

identify input. determine the data that is to be passed from the client to your application. input can take the following forms on the client-side:

url-based parameters
form-based parameters
hidden fields
cookies
understand the input. understand the use and constraints associated with each input. be clear how each input is used. define the format and type of each input. build a server-side validator for each format and type of expected input.

create a set of validators. build a validator for each type of input. place the set of validators on the server-side of your application. if there are validators on the client-side, make sure the same validators are implemented on the server-side as well. 

once developed, it is important to place the validation routines at your application's trust boundary. because your application's trust boundary extends only to your application's process space, the user's browser should not be considered a part of your application's trust boundary.

title: Stored XSS via crafted SVG file
description: Stored XSS via crafted SVG file
extra_info: every web application has  upload functionality in some cases upload functionality fail to protect against data validation which user uploaded and as result user script got executed to it server . file upload vulnerability is a vulnerability where an application allows a user to upload a malicious file directly which is then executed due to insecure file upload an attacker can perform different attack scenario it leads to os command injection , xss , ssrf etc .

restrict svg files or sanitize javascript from the svg data.
always filter files  and restrict the content-type of the uploaded files
implementing content security policy
always check metadata that upload file contain 
using svg sanitizer purifier tools libraries

step-1 : we uploaded not allowed file type i.e. svg as well as contents of svg file as per our wish which will eventually trigger xss 
step-2 : we intercepted the request during file upload and changed the extension from valid file - pdf to svg and replaced the contents of pdf with malicious svg content
step-3 : forwarded the request as well as intercepted the response to get file name m though file name and path can be fetched from html source code as well
step-4 : we then browsed the file in browser using link -  https://staging.techgig.com/zs/files/saas/users/1668609268_test.svg and we got the xss alert.
step-5 : refer poc attachments for the same
* application should have some request limiting factor if arriving in unorderly fashion or too quickly

step-1 :  application presents users with a discussion forum which allows users of application to post reply like pin delete their posting and other 
               users as well
step-2 :  since application also allow user to format their inputs like title and summary with html bold italic pointers , we tested the application for how  
                it is behaving for all html tag inputs
step-3 :  we brute-forced the posting features with all html tags and static title and summary values of test2
step-4 :  visited the discussion forum and noticed strange behaviour on how post are displayed leading to html injection
step-5 :   further , we tried deleting such posts but no such options were present to delete like reply to strange posts , though pin feature was 
                 available but not usable
step-6 :   we tried posting new content but were unable to do so as well features of formatting like bold italic pointers
step-7 :   we also noticed that discussion forum was visible the same way to other users also not allowing them to use it leading to application wide 
                 impact to all users 
step-8 :   checked after few hours , feature was still not usable
step-9 :   refer poc attachments which shows application feature state which is same for two different user as it is a public forum for all users , the 
                 attachments also implies that either of the user were not able to post anything
steps_to_reproduce:
step-1 :  application presents users with a discussion forum which allows users of application to post reply like pin delete their posting and other 
               users as well
step-2 :  since application also allow user to format their inputs like title and summary with html bold italic pointers , we tested the application for how  
                it is behaving for all html tag inputs
step-3 :  we brute-forced the posting features with all html tags and static title and summary values of test2
step-4 :  visited the discussion forum and noticed strange behaviour on how post are displayed leading to html injection
step-5 :   further , we tried deleting such posts but no such options were present to delete like reply to strange posts , though pin feature was 
                 available but not usable
step-6 :   we tried posting new content but were unable to do so as well features of formatting like bold italic pointers
step-7 :   we also noticed that discussion forum was visible the same way to other users also not allowing them to use it leading to application wide 
                 impact to all users 
step-8 :   checked after few hours , feature was still not usable
step-9 :   refer poc attachments which shows application feature state which is same for two different user as it is a public forum for all users , the 
                 attachments also implies that either of the user were not able to post anything
mitigation: * application should have some request limiting factor if arriving in unorderly fashion or too quickly

title: OTP Brute Force Attack
extra_info: here, it is also possible to bypass client side validation by capturing the otp request via proxy and also the time limit of 10 min for otp attempts can also be bypassed as we started our attack after completion of 10 minutes and successfully cracked otp in 20th attempt(sample for poc).
all the validations should be checked on server side.

step1:- click on submit button after entering otp and capture this request via proxy.
step2:- wait for 10 min and send this request to burp intruder for checking brute force attack.
step3:- after 10 min initiate the attack and we will successfully logged in 20th request.
steps_to_reproduce:
step1:- click on submit button after entering otp and capture this request via proxy.
step2:- wait for 10 min and send this request to burp intruder for checking brute force attack.
step3:- after 10 min initiate the attack and we will successfully logged in 20th request.
mitigation: all the validations should be checked on server side.

title: Weak Password Policy
extra_info:
a product's design should require adherance to an appropriate password policy. specific password requirements depend strongly on contextual factors, but it is recommended to contain the following attributes:-

enforcement of a minimum and maximum length.
restrictions against password reuse.
restrictions against using common passwords.
restrictions against using contextual string in the password (e.g., user id, app name).
depending on the threat model, the password policy may include several additional attributes.
complex passwords requiring mixed character sets (alpha, numeric, special, mixed case).

increasing the range of characters makes the password harder to crack and may be appropriate for systems relying on single factor authentication.

large minimum length (encouraging passphrases instead of passwords)
increasing the number of characters makes the password harder to crack and may be appropriate for systems relying on single factor authentication.

password expiration
requiring a periodic password change can reduce the time window that an adversary has to crack a password, while also limiting the damage caused by password exposures at other locations.
password expiration may be a good mitigating technique when long complex passwords are not desired.
mitigation:

title: Security Misconfiguration
extra_info: hide nginx version as an attacker might use the disclosed information to harvest specific security vulnerabilities for the version identified.

as there is no restriction on allowed size of text query parameter on /sms/v1/send endpoint , we injected string data of huge length and server gives out nginx server version which can further be used in various ways as a chain of attack.
refer poc
steps_to_reproduce:
as there is no restriction on allowed size of text query parameter on /sms/v1/send endpoint , we injected string data of huge length and server gives out nginx server version which can further be used in various ways as a chain of attack.
refer poc
mitigation: hide nginx version as an attacker might use the disclosed information to harvest specific security vulnerabilities for the version identified.

extra_info: use authentication / authorization mechanism to validate and authorize the users requesting the resource after verifying the user is who they say they are and have the rights to perform the actions \ view resources.

1. the request endpoint "https://stageapi.entpmsg.com/dlr/v1/dlrstatus?transactionid=5345435435&reciepientid=43543543535&recipient=9910604331&sender=practo&description=success_deli&totalpdu=1&message=testsms&deliverystatus=delivery_success&deliverydt=28-12-2022%2009:11:11&submitdt=28-12-2022%2009:11:10&corelationid=practo%7c%7c1abjbgghj" is missing authentication / authorization headers 
2. when we issue a request on mentioned endpoint , we notice that we are able to successfully post the request with a valid response back from the system.
3. since , we are able to issue a request and got a valid response back from system despite of the fact that there are no authentication / authorization headers present in the request , any user having access or idea about this api endpoint can issue the request which should not be the case
steps_to_reproduce:
1. the request endpoint "https://stageapi.entpmsg.com/dlr/v1/dlrstatus?transactionid=5345435435&reciepientid=43543543535&recipient=9910604331&sender=practo&description=success_deli&totalpdu=1&message=testsms&deliverystatus=delivery_success&deliverydt=28-12-2022%2009:11:11&submitdt=28-12-2022%2009:11:10&corelationid=practo%7c%7c1abjbgghj" is missing authentication / authorization headers 
2. when we issue a request on mentioned endpoint , we notice that we are able to successfully post the request with a valid response back from the system.
3. since , we are able to issue a request and got a valid response back from system despite of the fact that there are no authentication / authorization headers present in the request , any user having access or idea about this api endpoint can issue the request which should not be the case
mitigation: use authentication / authorization mechanism to validate and authorize the users requesting the resource after verifying the user is who they say they are and have the rights to perform the actions \ view resources.

title: Unrestricted file upload
extra_info:
step 1 : we uploaded a file of allowed mime-types (jpg/jpeg,png) as per existing edit profile functionality and recorded the successful response in burp proxy tool. please refer poc attached image.
step 2 : we uploaded a file named index.jsp which is not allowed as per existing edit profile functionality and noticed that we receive a successful response just like what we receive when we upload allowed file type.
this indicates that there is no validations performed on file type which leads to unrestricted file upload.

note : 
1. though we get a successful response after uploading not-allowed file type but when we reference it using the "picurl" value , we get the default image icon but we suspect that based on the success response that file may have been upload to mentioned domain & path -"https://mytimes.indiatimes.com/image/profile/26/815543525".
we would like to confirm whether this file exists over there and is uploaded.
please implement checks on file size and file type.

refer :
ssoid=6v0fu30pyhvklvububfhfl09u;
"picurl":"https://mytimes.indiatimes.com/image/profile/29/815543525"

step 2 : we uploaded a file named index.jsp which is not allowed as per existing edit profile functionality and noticed that we receive a successful response just like what we receive when we upload allowed file type.
this indicates that there is no validations performed on file type which leads to unrestricted file upload.

extra_info:
step 1 : as per jsso email verification flow , we added an email for which otp / code is delivered at to be verified email address.the email for otp mentions validity of 10 minutes.  
step 2 : after waiting for more than 10 minutes straight , we noticed that email otp verification is also allowed after 10 minutes which is against the jsso otp verification flow.
note : 
#this behaviour is not permanent as sometimes it gives up transaction_error when the validity is reached and code / otp is submitted.
#this allows an attacker with a wider time frame to bruteforce otp / code.
#we have checked the same flaw for mobile otp verification and it seems that otp is not usable after 10 minutes , if otp is used after 10 minutes , we 
get transaction_error in response.

on the course of testing , the allow rate limit came out to be 4 incorrect attempts and on 5th incorrect attempt , an error message via api is served "limit_exceeded" which makes it difficult for any attacker to bruteforce easily.

the "reauthenticate" functionality for email verification is also not honouring otp validity.

create new user.
send the otp request
edit the http response and set mobile_verification_otp_sent from true to false and send the response
check the app and otp page verification will be skipped

create the new user.
user the same create user request to edit the property of existing user
login to the app and it will give the weak token which is encrypted in md5… it have 3 parts,, first part is md5 of userid last part is md5 of user-agent(ios/android)

create new user.
send the otp request
edit the http response and set mobile_verification_otp_sent from true to false and send the response
check the app and otp page verification will be skipped

title: Reflected XSS
extra_info:
step 1 : we found out that the query parameter category can take on any arbitrary user specified input and reflects it back in response.
step 2 : when we supplied html special characters , our request was blocked with response status code "400 bad request" either due to the presence of waf or system / application input validation controls.
step 3 : but when we supplied url encoded html special characters , request was not blocked and went through and input got reflected in response with nothing encoded , context was html as well as javascript.
step 4 : we were able to inject some xss payloads uri/url encoded and trigger a basic alert as a part of detection phase.
step 5 : we exploited the xss and was able to steal user user session and personal information like email , user session etc.

application can be vulnerable at various endpoint and parameters , apply mitigation at all points , request dynamic and static scans for a wider coverage.
steps_to_reproduce:
step 1 : we found out that the query parameter category can take on any arbitrary user specified input and reflects it back in response.
step 2 : when we supplied html special characters , our request was blocked with response status code "400 bad request" either due to the presence of waf or system / application input validation controls.
step 3 : but when we supplied url encoded html special characters , request was not blocked and went through and input got reflected in response with nothing encoded , context was html as well as javascript.
step 4 : we were able to inject some xss payloads uri/url encoded and trigger a basic alert as a part of detection phase.
step 5 : we exploited the xss and was able to steal user user session and personal information like email , user session etc.

application can be vulnerable at various endpoint and parameters , apply mitigation at all points , request dynamic and static scans for a wider coverage.

title: TOI+ Subscription For 1 Year @Rs0
extra_info:
it is possible for a malicious user to get the toi+ subscription for 1 year @rs 0.0. we have exploited the above vulnerability by using brute force technique by finding different productid(for details check steps to produce and poc) to get subscriptions. and it is also possible to further exploit this using race condition to get toi+ membership for more than one year.
this will also lead to replay attack to exploit it to get membership for more than 1 month:

step1:-  go to the buy subscription plans and click on subscribe now or renew button by selecting any plan. 
step2:- in this request(post /subscriptions/order/android/create?cc=in&fv=925) we found that there is parameter "productid '':6 taking numeric values.
step3:- so we decided to change these numeric values and check the different responses for different productid's.
step4:- for quick check and bigger scope we have launched brute force attack on the "productid'':6 parameter and decided to check it for values 1 to 150 payloads.
step5:- here we found that for "productid '':''112" the amount is "payable":0.0 inr.
step4:- finally we successfully made the payment of rs 0 and got the membership for 1 years i.e from "startdate":"sat, 28 oct 2023 23:59:59 ist" to "enddate":"sun, 27 oct 2024 23:59:59 ist".

apply consistent controls across similar features and options.

the logical issue exists under ask feature of the application where users of the web application can ask questions and answers as well to the asked questions.
the feature comes with vote up / vote down options on the answers posted by the other users, here we have observed that any user can spam vote up / vote down on any answers including his own.
there's no limit on vote up / vote down options which allows any user to spam vote on any answer including his own , ideally either a single vote up / vote down should be the case per user.
any user can manipulate the number of vote counts on his answer or any other user answer.
step1: capture the vote update post request while intercept and send it to intruder. 
step2: clear all payload position markers and choose payload type as null payloads and start the attack for indefinite counts.
step3: stop the attack after sometime and check vote counts which will be drastically higher.
note : 
at the same time , vote down counts can be manipulated.
please refer poc for reference.
apply consistent controls across similar features and options.

about the issue : the application has an ask feature where users can post questions and answers , there is a trending discussion tab where question with most answer comes on trending discussion.
step1: to bring any discussion on trending , we can capture a answer request on any discussion and send it to intruder tab.
step2: clear all payload marker position , use attack type as sniper and payload type as null payload with indefinite payload counts then start the attack.
step3: after sometime , stop the attack and notice the answer count is in thousands which eventually brought the selected discussion in trending.

via this , any malicious user can bring discussion of his own or of his choice under trending.

ideally , there should be some daily limit on the number of answers a user can post within a stipulated time frame.
apply consistent controls across similar features and options.

the application allow users to follow unfollow masters as well as seekers .
step1: capture one of the follow request and send it to intruder tab.
step2: pay attention to "get /ajax/user-follow-unfollow/336/1 where 1 is to follow a user & 336 is master or seeker id
step3: under intruder tab , mark payload position at 336 and select number range from 1 to 5001 then start the attack.
step4: check the results of intruder attack where the user end up following all user_ids between range 1 to 5001.

application can put a limit on how many people you can follow every day to prevent accounts from spamming or breaking the community guidelines. if someone is following many accounts quickly, it may be for the wrong reasons. instagram wants you to follow accounts to enjoy the photos ,blogs ,posts that are uploaded shared via those accounts, not to make comments for self-promotion.

a malicious user can manipulate the opted limit at the  time of  registration of  card to 0$ or a negative amount value.
"opted_limit"  should be validated at the server side.

steps to produce:-
step1:- select  a limit and bank and click on continue.
step2:- capture this request(post /bank/save-credit-details) via proxy.
step3:- change the "opted_limit":50 to "opted_limit":0 or -50 and forward this request.
step4:- it will get successfully processed.
it is possible for a malicious user to generate more than one invitation link with different unique tokens for the same user with the same request .
for a single request only one link with the same token should be generated.

step1:- capture the request(post /users/get-invitation-details)  via proxy and send this to the intruder.
step2:- launch a replay attack for 10 simultaneous requests.
step3:- ten invitation links have been generated with different unique tokens for the same user with the same request.
a malicious user can update an address after completing the kyc process.
should validate the users who have already completed kyc and decline the request.

step2:- now manipulate the post parameters {"address_street", "address_city","address_subdivision","address_postal_code","address_country_code"}.

title: Sensitive Information Exposure on URL's
extra_info: sensitive information within urls may be logged in various locations, including the user's browser, the web server, and any forward or reverse proxy servers between the two endpoints. urls may also be displayed on-screen, bookmarked or emailed around by users. they may be disclosed to third parties via the referer header when any off-site links are followed. placing session tokens into the url increases the risk that they will be captured by an attacker.
applications should use an alternative mechanism for transmitting session tokens, such as http cookies or hidden fields in forms that are submitted using the post method.

title: Stored XSS
extra_info:
the application has various options under "create new" tab like article , rich stories etc 
step 1 : the create article option allows user to write article which includes inputs / entry points fields like title , body , synopsis and extra options like taxonomy , seo , collaboration which in itself has entry points / input fields for user to input.
step 2 : we used common xss payloads like script tag with alerts and placed them as inputs in title body synopsis input fields , the seo sub-feature also has inputs fields which were also found to be vulnerable to stored xss.
step 3 : similarly , input fields  of options under "create new" are also susceptible to stored xss.
step 4 : once the data is saved in db and then retrieved back , it triggers an alert leading to xss.

there are multiple defenses that can applied in current scenario to mitigate the issue like input validation , output encoding based upon the context where input is present in final response , input sanitization ,marking critical cookies as http-only so that it can't be read by client side js , waf , using response security header like csp , using framework and technology support to mitigate such issues.
steps_to_reproduce:
the application has various options under "create new" tab like article , rich stories etc 
step 1 : the create article option allows user to write article which includes inputs / entry points fields like title , body , synopsis and extra options like taxonomy , seo , collaboration which in itself has entry points / input fields for user to input.
step 2 : we used common xss payloads like script tag with alerts and placed them as inputs in title body synopsis input fields , the seo sub-feature also has inputs fields which were also found to be vulnerable to stored xss.
step 3 : similarly , input fields  of options under "create new" are also susceptible to stored xss.
step 4 : once the data is saved in db and then retrieved back , it triggers an alert leading to xss.

there are multiple defenses that can applied in current scenario to mitigate the issue like input validation , output encoding based upon the context where input is present in final response , input sanitization ,marking critical cookies as http-only so that it can't be read by client side js , waf , using response security header like csp , using framework and technology support to mitigate such issues.

title: Unrestricted file upload

extra_info:
about the feature :
the application has "request access" feature where a user can raise access request for channel and team under that channel.the access request goes to defined team leads under each channel and teams.
the request for approval goes to "http://coral.timesinternet.in/coral" which usually team leads has access to , the team leads can approve or decline request for access raised from users.
about the issue : 
the issue allows an attacker to capture the "access" request via proxy where he can tamper with the values of input parameters "approvers | requestedfor | requestor" as per his choice and directs the request to the system.
step 1 : we captured the request via intercept and added ourself as an approver and forwarded the request to the backend system.
step 2 : assuming if we have access to coral platform then we would receive the request for approval even if the user is not part of that channel and team.
step 3 : we confirmed the issue as we received email for access request even if we were not part of any channel and teams approvers list.
conclusion , user or in current case team leads having access to coral platform can become approver of teams and channel of which they are not part of and approve request for any user.
please refer poc for more details.

title: Sensitive Information Disclosure (card Data of customer)
description: Sensitive Information Disclosure (card Data of customer)
extra_info:
preventing information disclosure completely is tricky due to the huge variety of ways in which it can occur. however, there are some general best practices that you can follow to minimize the risk of these kinds of vulnerability creeping into your own websites.

make sure that everyone involved in producing the website is fully aware of what information is considered sensitive. sometimes seemingly harmless information can be much more useful to an attacker than people realize. highlighting these dangers can help make sure that sensitive information is handled more securely in general by your organization.
audit any code for potential information disclosure as part of your qa or build processes. it should be relatively easy to automate some of the associated tasks, such as stripping developer comments.
use generic error messages as much as possible. don't provide attackers with clues about application behavior unnecessarily.
double-check that any debugging or diagnostic features are disabled in the production environment.
make sure you fully understand the configuration settings, and security implications, of any third-party technology that you implement. take the time to investigate and disable any features and settings that you don't actually need.

step1:- capture the request(get /bank/card-details/v1/2196b0ba-9de9-414a-9a76-7fb620af6c45?unified_response=false)

mitigation:
preventing information disclosure completely is tricky due to the huge variety of ways in which it can occur. however, there are some general best practices that you can follow to minimize the risk of these kinds of vulnerability creeping into your own websites.

make sure that everyone involved in producing the website is fully aware of what information is considered sensitive. sometimes seemingly harmless information can be much more useful to an attacker than people realize. highlighting these dangers can help make sure that sensitive information is handled more securely in general by your organization.
audit any code for potential information disclosure as part of your qa or build processes. it should be relatively easy to automate some of the associated tasks, such as stripping developer comments.
use generic error messages as much as possible. don't provide attackers with clues about application behavior unnecessarily.
double-check that any debugging or diagnostic features are disabled in the production environment.
make sure you fully understand the configuration settings, and security implications, of any third-party technology that you implement. take the time to investigate and disable any features and settings that you don't actually need.

an ssrf exploit that causes connections to external third-party systems might result in malicious onward attacks that appear to originate from the organization hosting the vulnerable application, leading to potential legal liabilities and reputational damage.

title: Authentication Bypass - MD5 Encryption
extra_info: an attacker gains access to application, service, or device with the privileges of an authorized or privileged user by evading or circumventing an authentication mechanism. the attacker is therefore able to access protected data without authentication ever having taken place. this refers to an attacker gaining access equivalent to an authenticated user without ever going through an authentication procedure. this is usually the result of the attacker using an unexpected access procedure that does not go through the proper checkpoints where authentication should occur. for example, a web site might assume that all users will click through a given link in order to get to secure material and simply authenticate everyone that clicks the link. however, an attacker might be able to reach secured web content by explicitly entering the path to the content rather than clicking through the authentication link, thereby avoiding the check entirely. this attack pattern differs from other authentication attacks in that attacks of this pattern avoid authentication entirely, rather than faking authentication by exploiting flaws or by stealing credentials from legitimate users.
application is transmitted the password in weak encryption format which is md5 sum of "mocha". same password is use for all the user roles present in the application.
use the strong encryption method or salting.
login to the app and intercept the request, application is sending password in md5.
steps_to_reproduce: login to the app and intercept the request, application is sending password in md5.
mitigation: use the strong encryption method or salting.

title: HTML Injection
extra_info: html injection is an attack that is similar to cross-site scripting (xss). while in the xss vulnerability the attacker can inject and execute javascript code, the html injection attack only allows the injection of certain html tags. when an application does not properly handle user supplied data, an attacker can supply valid html code, typically via a parameter value, and inject their own content into the page. this attack is typically used in conjunction with some form of social engineering, as the attack is exploiting a code-based vulnerability and a user's trust

impact:- this vulnerability can have many consequences, like disclosure of a user's session
cookies that could be used to impersonate the victim, or, more generally, it can allow the
attacker to modify the page content seen by the victims.

mitigation : script should filter metacharacters from user input.

title: Lack or Misconfiguration of Security Headers
description: Lack or Misconfiguration of Security Headers
extra_info: the application fails to prevent users from connecting to it over unencrypted connections. an attacker able to modify a legitimate user's network traffic could bypass the application's use of ssl/tls encryption, and use the application as a platform for attacks against its users. this attack is performed by rewriting https links as http, so that if a targeted user follows a link to the site from an http page, their browser never attempts to use an encrypted connection. the sslstrip tool automates this process.

to exploit this vulnerability, an attacker must be suitably positioned to intercept and modify the victim's network traffic.this scenario typically occurs when a client communicates with the server over an insecure connection such as public wi-fi, or a corporate or home network that is shared with a compromised computer. common defenses such as switched networks are not sufficient to prevent this. an attacker situated in the user's isp or the application's hosting infrastructure could also perform this attack. note that an advanced adversary could potentially target any connection made over the internet's core infrastructure.

the application should instruct web browsers to only access the application using https. to do this, enable http strict transport security (hsts) by adding a response header with the name 'strict-transport-security' and the value 'max-age=expiretime', where expiretime is the time in seconds that browsers should remember that the site should only be accessed using https. consider adding the 'includesubdomains' flag if appropriate.
note that because hsts is a "trust on first use" (tofu) protocol, a user who has never accessed the application will never have seen the hsts header, and will therefore still be vulnerable to ssl stripping attacks. to mitigate this risk, you can optionally add the 'preload' flag to the hsts header, and submit the domain for review by browser vendors.

login to the app
intercept the request
check the http response header, hsts header is missing

title: Stored XSS
extra_info:
steps to produce

the application has various options under "create new" tab like article , rich stories etc
step 1 : the create article option allows user to write article which includes inputs / entry points fields like title , body , synopsis and extra options like taxonomy , seo , collaboration which in itself has entry points / input fields for user to input.
step 2 : we used common xss payloads like script tag with alerts and placed them as inputs in title body synopsis input fields , the seo sub-feature also has inputs fields which were also found to be vulnerable to stored xss.
step 3 : similarly , input fields of options under "create new" are also susceptible to stored xss.
step 4 : once the data is saved in db and then retrieved back , it triggers an alert leading to xss.

there are multiple defenses that can applied in current scenario to mitigate the issue like input validation , output encoding based upon the context where input is present in final response , input sanitization ,marking critical cookies as http-only so that it can't be read by client side js , waf , using response security header like csp , using framework and technology support to mitigate such issues.

step 4 : once the data is saved in db and then retrieved back , it triggers an alert leading to xss.

extra_info:
about the feature :
the application has "request access" feature where a user can raise access request for channel and team under that channel.the access request goes to defined team leads under each channel and teams.
the request for approval goes to "http://coral.timesinternet.in/coral" which usually team leads has access to , the team leads can approve or decline request for access raised from users.
about the issue :
the issue allows an attacker to capture the "access" request via proxy where he can tamper with the values of input parameters "approvers | requestedfor | requestor" as per his choice and directs the request to the system.
step 1 : we captured the request via intercept and added ourself as an approver and forwarded the request to the backend system.
step 2 : assuming if we have access to coral platform then we would receive the request for approval even if the user is not part of that channel and team.
step 3 : we confirmed the issue as we received email for access request even if we were not part of any channel and teams approvers list.
conclusion , user or in current case team leads having access to coral platform can become approver of teams and channel of which they are not part of and approve request for any user.
please refer poc for more details.

title: Sensitive Information Exposure on URL's
extra_info:
regardless of using encryption, the following url will expose information in the locations detailed below: https://vulnerablehost.com/authuser?user=bob&authz_token=1234&expire=1500000000

the parameter values for user, authz_token, and expire will be exposed in the following locations when using http or https:

referer header
web logs
shared systems
browser history
browser cache
shoulder surfing
when not using an encrypted channel, all of the above and the following:

man-in-the-middle

this may lead to sensitive data exposure "if unauthorized parties have access to the urls via server logs, referrer header or browser history."

sending sensitive data in post body will prevent data from being logged in various places like browser history , web server logs , proxy logs etc.
use encrypted channel to prevent traffic interception by an attacker on same unprotected network

application is sending sensitive information like sso token and jwt as a part of get method query parameter 
please refer poc
exposure proof-of-concept
an internal attacker can potentially exploit this vulnerability as the request above is captured in the server logs even when requested via an encrypted channel
steps_to_reproduce:
application is sending sensitive information like sso token and jwt as a part of get method query parameter 
please refer poc
exposure proof-of-concept
an internal attacker can potentially exploit this vulnerability as the request above is captured in the server logs even when requested via an encrypted channel
mitigation:
sending sensitive data in post body will prevent data from being logged in various places like browser history , web server logs , proxy logs etc.
use encrypted channel to prevent traffic interception by an attacker on same unprotected network
