title: Improper Error Handling
extra_info: application throws an error when providing invalid input or invalid file type , please refer poc screenshot
steps_to_reproduce: application throws an error when providing invalid input or invalid file type , please refer poc screenshot

extra_info: many security problems arise with web application because clients can submit arbitrary input. some web applications rely solely on client-side controls to control the data that they submit to the server. in general, this represents a fundamental security flaw: the user has full control over the client and the data it submits and can bypass any client-side controls that are not replicated on the server.

note: client-side javascript routines to validate user input are common in web applications, but it should not be concluded that every such application is vulnerable. 

the application is exposed only if client-side validation is not replicated on the server, and even then only if crafted input that circumvents client-side validation can be used to cause some undesirable behavior by the application.

implement server-side validation: client-side validation is a necessary measure, but it should be complemented with server-side validation. server-side validation is more secure since it is not dependent on the client and can provide more comprehensive checks.

use frameworks and libraries that provide built-in validation: many modern web frameworks and libraries come with built-in validation that can be used to implement robust validation checks for input data.

implement strict input sanitization: ensure that input data is sanitized to prevent the injection of malicious code or special characters that can bypass validation checks.

use content security policy (csp): csp is a security mechanism that allows website owners to specify which types of content are allowed to be loaded on their website. this can help prevent injection of malicious scripts and code.

stay up-to-date with security patches and updates: keep your web application and any third-party libraries up-to-date with the latest security patches and updates.

implement access controls: access controls can help prevent unauthorized access to sensitive parts of the application and help protect against attacks that bypass validation.

educate users: educate users on the importance of not manipulating form submissions, using trusted sources for input, and avoiding suspicious links or attachments.
please refer pdf for detailed explanation.
steps_to_reproduce: please refer pdf for detailed explanation.
mitigation:
implement server-side validation: client-side validation is a necessary measure, but it should be complemented with server-side validation. server-side validation is more secure since it is not dependent on the client and can provide more comprehensive checks.

use frameworks and libraries that provide built-in validation: many modern web frameworks and libraries come with built-in validation that can be used to implement robust validation checks for input data.

implement strict input sanitization: ensure that input data is sanitized to prevent the injection of malicious code or special characters that can bypass validation checks.

use content security policy (csp): csp is a security mechanism that allows website owners to specify which types of content are allowed to be loaded on their website. this can help prevent injection of malicious scripts and code.

stay up-to-date with security patches and updates: keep your web application and any third-party libraries up-to-date with the latest security patches and updates.

implement access controls: access controls can help prevent unauthorized access to sensitive parts of the application and help protect against attacks that bypass validation.

educate users: educate users on the importance of not manipulating form submissions, using trusted sources for input, and avoiding suspicious links or attachments.
impact:
note: client-side javascript routines to validate user input are common in web applications, but it should not be concluded that every such application is vulnerable. 

the application is exposed only if client-side validation is not replicated on the server, and even then only if crafted input that circumvents client-side validation can be used to cause some undesirable behavior by the application.

title: HTML Injection
extra_info: html injection is an attack that is similar to cross-site scripting (xss). while in the xss vulnerability the attacker can inject and execute javascript code, the html injection attack only allows the injection of certain html tags. when an application does not properly handle user supplied data, an attacker can supply valid html code, typically via a parameter value, and inject their own content into the page. this attack is typically used in conjunction with some form of social engineering, as the attack is exploiting a code-based vulnerability and a user's trust

impact:- this vulnerability can have many consequences, like disclosure of a user's session
cookies that could be used to impersonate the victim, or, more generally, it can allow the
attacker to modify the page content seen by the victims.

mitigation : script should filter metacharacters from user input.

step 1 : in raw stories , supplied image tag as input.
step 2 : on saving , it got rendered without sanitization and output encoding.

extra_info:
failing to handle unconventional input
one aim of the application logic is to restrict user input to values that adhere to the business rules. for example, the application may be designed to accept arbitrary values of a certain data type, but the logic determines whether or not this value is acceptable from the perspective of the business. many applications incorporate numeric limits into their logic. this might include limits designed to manage inventory, apply budgetary restrictions, trigger phases of the supply chain, and so on.

let's take the simple example of an online shop. when ordering products, users typically specify the quantity that they want to order. although any integer is theoretically a valid input, the business logic might prevent users from ordering more units than are currently in stock, for example.

to implement rules like this, developers need to anticipate all possible scenarios and incorporate ways to handle them into the application logic. in other words, they need to tell the application whether it should allow a given input and how it should react based on various conditions. if there is no explicit logic for handling a given case, this can lead to unexpected and potentially exploitable behavior.

for example, a numeric data type might accept negative values. depending on the related functionality, it may not make sense for the business logic to allow this. however, if the application doesn't perform adequate server-side validation and reject this input, an attacker may be able to pass in a negative value and induce unwanted behavior.

the application hosts various functionality where there is no input validation on the limit and length of input provided , be it alphabetic or numeric. 
please validate input and check whether it strictly adheres to business logic rules.

application holds password reset functionality were email is required to enter email to reset password and gets a response back from application. 

step 1 : we curated a list of emails from public means as a part of information gathering phase , social engineering. 
step 2 : we send the request to intruder then mark the input email as placeholder for payload position.
step 3 : provided the list of emails as payload simple list.
step 4 : we start the attack and wait till the attack is finished.
step 5 : let's view the results and notice the response content , status code and response length.
step 6 : response content is enough to come to conclusion that which user exists and which doesn't. 
step 7 : if a valid user exists then response served back from application is "reset".
step 8 : if a user doesn't exists then response served back from application is ""message":"no user found" and status code is 404.

title: Horizontal Privilege Escalation
extra_info:
#developers must not rely on frontend for security of the application as it can be bypassed using any proxy tools intercept / repeater feature.
#always validate at server side the expected structure of the request with allowed parameter(s) and their values.

reference:- https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/owasp_top_ten_2017/top_10-2017_a5-broken_access_control

the application has users functionality where the admin can add , delete , edit users.

step 1 : we explored cms users page where we can add users to the backend with roles : roles_admin and roles_customer_support_admin , the endpoint is https://dev.timesclub.co/cms/app/cms-user/0.
step 2 : while going through http proxy history generated while exploring cms users feature , we found a http request which leaks all existing user roles in http response to an http which queries existing users.
step 3 : we created a user as. a part of regular request flow and later on we edit the same user and attach the new permission of neo_bank_admin to update request.
step 4 : upon doing this , we checked update request is successful just like a regular request.
step 5 : we again checked the same http request via which we enumerated neobank_admin user roles and confirmed that our user shubham singh has now access to all roles.

the application hosts endpoint at https://dev.timesclub.co/cms/app/cms-user/0 which creates a suspicion that another feature may be existing at https://dev.timesclub.co/cms/app/cms-user/1.
in this application , we observed the same , it revealed that by providing 1 instead of 0 , we see the same ui but with extra feature of turning user active .
the application also rendered three user roles inconsistently while exploring the app.
steps_to_reproduce:
the application has users functionality where the admin can add , delete , edit users.

step 1 : we explored cms users page where we can add users to the backend with roles : roles_admin and roles_customer_support_admin , the endpoint is https://dev.timesclub.co/cms/app/cms-user/0.
step 2 : while going through http proxy history generated while exploring cms users feature , we found a http request which leaks all existing user roles in http response to an http which queries existing users.
step 3 : we created a user as. a part of regular request flow and later on we edit the same user and attach the new permission of neo_bank_admin to update request.
step 4 : upon doing this , we checked update request is successful just like a regular request.
step 5 : we again checked the same http request via which we enumerated neobank_admin user roles and confirmed that our user shubham singh has now access to all roles.

the application hosts endpoint at https://dev.timesclub.co/cms/app/cms-user/0 which creates a suspicion that another feature may be existing at https://dev.timesclub.co/cms/app/cms-user/1.
in this application , we observed the same , it revealed that by providing 1 instead of 0 , we see the same ui but with extra feature of turning user active .
the application also rendered three user roles inconsistently while exploring the app.
mitigation:
#developers must not rely on frontend for security of the application as it can be bypassed using any proxy tools intercept / repeater feature.
#always validate at server side the expected structure of the request with allowed parameter(s) and their values.

reference:- https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/owasp_top_ten_2017/top_10-2017_a5-broken_access_control

title: Vertical Privilege Escalation
extra_info:
we have two users with unique roles : 
user : vikas.kumar        role : ["role_admin"]
user : rohit.choudhary role : ["role_admin","cs_neobank_admin","role_customer_support_admin"]

ideally , users with two different roles shouldn't be able to access each other resources if they share same access level or different access level.the access type can be state changing  (post method) , resource gathering (get method) etc.

we were able to access resources of user with role "neo_bank_admin" with jwt token of another user with role "role_admin".please refer below points to understand better : 

step 1 : we logged in to cms portal using account of user rohit having role of ["role_admin","cs_neobank_admin","role_customer_support_admin"] and accessed resources of neo_bank functionality which gets logged in burp's http proxy history.

step 2 : we sent all the request relating to neo_bank feature from burp's http history to repeater , the requests as of now belongs to user rohit having role of neo_bank_admin.

step 3 : we replaced jwt of user rohit with user vikas and issues the request to access the same resources and application served back the neonbank resources to user vikas even after the he is possessing is of only admin.
step 2 :



note : at frontend (ui) level , the restriction is at place but can be bypassed using proxy tool.

title: Indirect Object Reference
extra_info:
the application has reports tab under left hand side of the panel which when explored generated a few http requests out of which one seemed quite interesting to us , that particular http request was https://cmsanalyticsstg.indiatimes.com/analyticswebapi/report/suggestion/mail (refer screenshot - emails_enumerated)

as a part of reports tab functionality , we created a report which will appear under the saved report tab.

the saved reports data will be fetched using http request https://cmsanalyticsstg.indiatimes.com/analyticswebapi/report/list/2/shubham.singh2@timesinternet.in (refer screenshot - normal_list_view)

we found above request interesting due to following reasons : 
post method request with no body
report type and user_email used in the url path probably being used for deciding to fetch resources and objects.
since , it is likely that the application here is using report_type and user_email to fetch other users resources and objects by changing report_type and user_emails.

we have already enumerated some valid users' email via suggestion/mail endpoint , the type of escalation will depend on the user role of all emails enumerated.
if the email of the users enumerated and our user email is having the same role then it is idor with horizontal privilege escalation else if it is email of higher user role then it is idor with vertical privilege escalation.






step 1.1 : we sent the request https://cmsanalyticsstg.indiatimes.com/analyticswebapi/report/list/2/shubham.singh2@timesinternet.in  to burp intruder and marked position for report_type and user_email and then provided valid payload data for each position and selected attack type as cluster-bomb.
note : payload position 1 with number from 1 - 18
           payload position 2 with the emails we enumerated using suggestion/mail endpoint 

step 1.2 : now , start the attack and when the attack is finished , confirm the status code to be 200 ok then sort the result by length.
we noticed that there is a difference in length for each request pointing to the fact there is some different response served by the server which needs to be investigated further.

step 1.3 : we analyzed the response data and noticed that we are able to see objects of other users just by changing user_email and report_type.

here , we can confirm the application is vulnerable to idor vulnerability leading to broken access control which allows us to view data of other users existing in the application.

as we were able to see report data of other users , the response was leaking report id which is actually uid , generally used as a defense in depth approach for access control attacks as these values are highly unguessable but since these values itself are leaked in response using idor , the mitigation strategy is left useless.

step 1.4 : using report id , we were able to delete other user reports by firing a post request for delete and replacing id with the one enumerated via idor.we can confirm the operation was successful as we received 1 in response with status code as 200.

to further confirm whether the report is deleted for that user or not , we again went back to view the report data for the same user where we can confirm that the report is deleted.

step 1.5 : we were also able to create reports for other users just by intercepting register requests for reports and changing user_email to any user for which we want to target , in response we got report id and all genuine responses just like any other regular response for the same register report request response.

step 1.6 : we were able to change the schedule for email and to_users list to anyone we would to send email with a report for any user.
for example , we were able to successfully change frequency from biweekly friday to friday, monday and to_list from aman.mittal to aman.mittal , shubham.singh2 , prakhar.agnihotri which was a schedule created by user gyan.prakash.

this is highly critical and sensitive as the report might contain very sensitive and business related data.

developers should avoid displaying private object references such as keys or file names.
validation of parameters should be properly implemented.
verification of all the referenced objects should be done.
tokens should be generated in such a way that it should only be mapped to the user and should not be public.

in summary, fixing idor vulnerabilities requires a combination of proper access controls, user input validation, and the use of indirect references to access objects or data. by implementing these measures, you can significantly reduce the risk of idor-related security issues in your application.

the application triggers few http requests out of which we sent https://cmsanalyticsstg.indiatimes.com/analyticswebapi/fetch/data/keywordstats http post request to burp repeater which includes some body parameter when we visit "keywords tab" on the left side panel.

 there is a normal response when re-send request from burp repeater.

step 1 : we first deleted one filter value and noticed there is no change in the response
step 2 : we tried another field value and again noticed that there is no change in the response , we tested this one by one .
step 3 : now , we deleted both parameter field value & parameter value value and noticed that now application is servinga large response compared to above cases and normal valid case.

the application is not checking/validating input parameter values in the incoming http request  and serving unexpected responses which at some times lead excessive data leakage , information disclosure as application has now received unexpected values in requests input parameter.

the application should be strictly checking input parameters in incoming request and validate that if the inputs values are expected or not , if not , the application shouldn't serve the client and reject the request with some generic and information message.

this also allowed us to gain unauthorized access to data which weren't supposed to be visible to user.

another issue is , application is not validating input length , inputs allowed while taking input from the user , validation is missing at client and server side all in all.

 there is a normal response when re-send request from burp repeater.

step 1 : we first deleted one filter value and noticed there is no change in the response
step 2 : we tried another field value and again noticed that there is no change in the response , we tested this one by one .
step 3 : now , we deleted both parameter field value & parameter value value and noticed that now application is servinga large response compared to above cases and normal valid case.

the application is not checking/validating input parameter values in the incoming http request  and serving unexpected responses which at some times lead excessive data leakage , information disclosure as application has now received unexpected values in requests input parameter.

the application should be strictly checking input parameters in incoming request and validate that if the inputs values are expected or not , if not , the application shouldn't serve the client and reject the request with some generic and information message.

extra_info:
broken authentication known as authentication bypass. this occurs when logic flaws or poor coding in the authentication implementation allow attackers to bypass the authentication process entirely and gain unauthorized access to a system or application. this is a severe security vulnerability that can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, and other malicious activities.

___________________________________________________________________________________________

causes of authentication bypass:

inadequate access controls: insufficient checks and controls in the code may allow an attacker to access protected resources or perform actions without proper authentication.

improper validation: insufficient input validation and trust in user input can lead to flaws in the authentication logic that can be exploited by attackers.

session management issues: weaknesses in session management, such as not checking session tokens correctly, can allow attackers to forge valid session tokens and gain unauthorized access.

insecure direct object references (idor): if an application doesn't properly validate and authorize user requests for specific resources, attackers can manipulate urls or other parameters to access objects or data they shouldn't have access to.

input validation and sanitization:

implement strong input validation and sanitization to ensure that user input cannot be used to manipulate authentication flows.
use a web application firewall (waf) to block malicious input and requests.
access control and authorization:

enforce strict access control policies based on user roles and permissions.
implement proper authorization checks at every level of the application, including the server-side and client-side code.
session management:

use strong session management techniques and libraries provided by the framework or platform.
always regenerate session tokens after authentication.
employ session fixation protection mechanisms.
secure direct object references (dor):

avoid exposing internal object references in urls or other user-controlled parameters.
use indirect object references (e.g., mapping objects to a unique token) and ensure proper authorization checks before accessing objects.
thorough code review and testing:

conduct code reviews with a focus on authentication and access control logic.
implement automated and manual testing to identify vulnerabilities like authentication bypass.
use security testing tools to scan for vulnerabilities.
security headers:

utilize security headers like content security policy (csp) and x-content-type-options to enhance security.
web application firewall (waf):

employ a waf that can help identify and block common attack patterns and malicious requests.
user and developer education:

train developers to be aware of authentication bypass risks and coding practices.
educate users about the importance of strong passwords and security best practices.
regular updates and patch management:

keep all software components, libraries, and frameworks up to date to mitigate known vulnerabilities.
monitoring and incident response:

implement real-time monitoring for suspicious activity and unauthorized access.
have an incident response plan in place to respond quickly to security incidents.

the application allows access to cmsanalytics via jsso login : 

step 1 : we provided our ad login credentials on jsso domain https://jssostg.indiatimes.com/sso/ldap/identity/login?ru=http://cmsanalyticsstg.indiatimes.com/analyticswebapi/auth/sso and if login details are correct , we are validated and temp-code is generated in the response which will be used in subsequent request to take it to the main application domain.
 
step 2 : there is an http post request following the get request just after the jsso login request.
the response to http post request https://cmsanalyticsstg.indiatimes.com/analyticswebapi/auth/getloggedinuserdetails is particularly interesting to us as it has some parameters in the response which might be getting used by the application in some manner.
so , we manipulated the username , user_email response parameters while in intercept then submitted the response to the client.

step 3 : once , we submitted the request to the client , the all following subsequent requests automatically fetched email and username provided in the response parameter and reflected the data of that particular user.

the application is having poor implementation of authentication flowand no access-control checks.

title: Horizontal Privilege Escalation
extra_info: here, it is possible for a malicious user to change the primary team of other user without having access to that team.

never rely on obfuscation alone for access control.
unless a resource is intended to be publicly accessible, deny access by default.
wherever possible, use a single application-wide mechanism for enforcing access controls.
at the code level, make it mandatory for developers to declare the access that is allowed for each resource, and deny access by default.
thoroughly audit and test access controls to ensure they work as designed.
reference:- https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/owasp_top_ten_2017/top_10-2017_a5-broken_access_control

step1:- go to permission ----> user access.
step2:- in the email id section type the official email id for granting access.
step3:- here, the user's primary team is "all mirrors" and i have access to set the primary team of the user to absolute radio team.
step4:- now in the action column click on "set as primary" and capture this request via proxy.
step5:- now tamper the parameter "teamuuid" form "absoluteradio" to "happytrips" .
step6:- user's primary team will get successfully set to "happytrips", though i don't have access to this team.
steps_to_reproduce:
step1:- go to permission ----> user access.
step2:- in the email id section type the official email id for granting access.
step3:- here, the user's primary team is "all mirrors" and i have access to set the primary team of the user to absolute radio team.
step4:- now in the action column click on "set as primary" and capture this request via proxy.
step5:- now tamper the parameter "teamuuid" form "absoluteradio" to "happytrips" .
step6:- user's primary team will get successfully set to "happytrips", though i don't have access to this team.
mitigation:
never rely on obfuscation alone for access control.
unless a resource is intended to be publicly accessible, deny access by default.
wherever possible, use a single application-wide mechanism for enforcing access controls.
at the code level, make it mandatory for developers to declare the access that is allowed for each resource, and deny access by default.
thoroughly audit and test access controls to ensure they work as designed.
reference:- https://owasp.org/www-project-top-ten/owasp_top_ten_2017/top_10-2017_a5-broken_access_control

title: hard coded sensitive information
extra_info:
disclosing an api key in client-side javascript code in a react application can have significant security implications, and it is generally not recommended. here are some of the potential security risks and considerations: 

unauthorized access: when you embed an api key in client-side code, anyone who views your web application's source code can easily access the api key. this makes it possible for malicious actors to use your api key for their purposes, such as making unauthorized requests to the associated api, potentially incurring costs or abusing the service.

data exposure: depending on the api you're accessing with the key, sensitive data or functionality may be exposed to unauthorized parties if they gain access to the key. this could lead to data breaches or misuse of your api.

rate limiting and quotas: many apis have rate limiting and usage quotas. if your api key is exposed and someone uses it to make excessive requests, it can lead to rate limiting or service disruptions for your application.

api key rotation: if you need to change or rotate your api keys for security reasons (e.g., if the key is compromised), having the key hard-coded in your client-side code can make this process more challenging and disruptive.

to mitigate these security risks, consider the following best practices:

server-side proxy: instead of making api requests directly from the client-side code, set up a server-side component (e.g., a back-end server or proxy) that securely manages the api key. the client-side code can then make requests to your server, and the server can authenticate with the api using the api key. this approach keeps the key secure on the server, away from the client-side code.

environment variables: if you must include an api key in your client-side code (e.g., for public apis where rate limiting is not a concern), consider using environment variables or configuration files to store the key. during the build process, you can inject these values into your javascript code. this approach keeps the key out of the source code repository and lessens the risk of accidental disclosure.

access control: implement proper access control and authentication on the server-side to ensure that only authorized users or components can access the api with the key.

rate limiting: implement rate limiting and usage monitoring on the server-side to protect against abuse of your api key, even when it's used from a server.

api key rotation: be prepared to rotate or regenerate api keys if they are ever exposed or compromised. using a server-side proxy makes this process more manageable.

remember that once an api key is exposed, it's challenging to revoke or regain control over it, and the potential consequences can be costly and disruptive. therefore, it's essential to follow best practices for securing api keys and minimize their exposure in client-side code
steps_to_reproduce: review html response javascript code
mitigation:
to mitigate these security risks, consider the following best practices:

server-side proxy: instead of making api requests directly from the client-side code, set up a server-side component (e.g., a back-end server or proxy) that securely manages the api key. the client-side code can then make requests to your server, and the server can authenticate with the api using the api key. this approach keeps the key secure on the server, away from the client-side code.

environment variables: if you must include an api key in your client-side code (e.g., for public apis where rate limiting is not a concern), consider using environment variables or configuration files to store the key. during the build process, you can inject these values into your javascript code. this approach keeps the key out of the source code repository and lessens the risk of accidental disclosure.

access control: implement proper access control and authentication on the server-side to ensure that only authorized users or components can access the api with the key.

rate limiting: implement rate limiting and usage monitoring on the server-side to protect against abuse of your api key, even when it's used from a server.

api key rotation: be prepared to rotate or regenerate api keys if they are ever exposed or compromised. using a server-side proxy makes this process more manageable.

remember that once an api key is exposed, it's challenging to revoke or regain control over it, and the potential consequences can be costly and disruptive. therefore, it's essential to follow best practices for securing api keys and minimize their exposure in client-side code

title: Sensitive Information Exposure on URL's
extra_info: the web api uses the http get method to process a request and includes sensitive information in the query string of that request.

the query string for the url could be saved in the browser's history, passed through referers to other websites, stored in web logs, or otherwise recorded in other sources. if the query string contains sensitive information such as session identifiers, passwords etc. then attackers can use this information to launch further attacks.
when sensitive information(username, passwords, token, etc.) is sent, use the post method.

title: Unrestricted file upload
extra_info: perform content validation as per file extension and mapped mime type

the file upload functionality allows us to upload file with malicious contents and stay within server file system which can be access via unique url allocated to the uploaded file.

step 1 : upload a file using frontend ui and capture the post upload request via proxy intercept and change the contents of the file to something malicious or mime type not allowed.

step 2 : forward the request and intercept the response as well , notice the file is uploaded successfully with incorrect content type according to file extension and mime type.

step 3 : we cannot see the file on frontend ui but from captured successful response , use uploadid and replace it with a genuine url of any resource image .

step 4 : when we hit the url , the malicious contents can be seen but are not executed by the server .

the file upload functionality misses on content verification for any file type which may sometime allow code script execution if some misconfiguration takes place at server level due to future changes.

title: Broken Access Control
extra_info:
the dam application is used to host media files and document files for other application which can pull data from here , the application provides users to create collection and add media and doc files to it.
but we observed that by changing the user email id , we can create collection for other users and also , we can create collection under different datasource by changing the datasource.

step 1 : we sent the http request for collection creation to repeater and fired the request which gave us a successful 200 ok response.
step 2 : now , we change the user email to some other existing user and sent the request and got a successful response which indicates that a new collection is created under that user and by user .
step 3 : also , datasource can be manipulated which will create the collection under provided datasource , in our case , we changed it langgetty , since we do not have access to langgetty so we can't see it but it is created under langgetty based upon successful response.
steps_to_reproduce:
the dam application is used to host media files and document files for other application which can pull data from here , the application provides users to create collection and add media and doc files to it.
but we observed that by changing the user email id , we can create collection for other users and also , we can create collection under different datasource by changing the datasource.

step 1 : we sent the http request for collection creation to repeater and fired the request which gave us a successful 200 ok response.
step 2 : now , we change the user email to some other existing user and sent the request and got a successful response which indicates that a new collection is created under that user and by user .
step 3 : also , datasource can be manipulated which will create the collection under provided datasource , in our case , we changed it langgetty , since we do not have access to langgetty so we can't see it but it is created under langgetty based upon successful response.

title: Stored XSS
extra_info:
the cms panel has news add and edit feature under content tab where it allows users of the platform to provide input as per the defined format.

step 1 : we tried basic xss script payload  but it didn't work.
step 2 : next ,  we tried with img tag and saved the news article , just upon saving the article , we got an alert pop up indicating   xss vulnerability.
step 3 : the type of xss concluded is stored xss as data is stored in backend data store and served back to user at later point of time.
step 4 : as a normal flow of the application , we published the article as well and stored xss is also visible on staging.indiatimes.com where impact is critical.

impact :
if any user of the cms application visit our article then we can steal his / her cookies 
if the published article is viewed by the main application where the article is pushed , the stored xss can steal all those users cookies who visits this article.

we can lure users to visit article by any means like pasting the link in chat box , public forums , emails etc


ck editor - configuration 
dompurifier - unwated tags which executes js code | plugins for dom purifier 
no html at all - we use server side encoding
in this case  , we are allowing users so we use dom purifier

cve-2020-11023, cve-2020-23064: passing html containing  elements from untrusted sources - even after sanitizing it - to one of jquery's dom manipulation methods (i.e. .html(), .append(), and others) may execute untrusted code.

extra_info: race conditions are a common type of vulnerability closely related to business logic flaws. they occur when websites process requests concurrently without adequate safeguards. this can lead to multiple distinct threads interacting with the same data at the same time, resulting in a "collision" that causes unintended behavior in the application. a race condition attack uses carefully timed requests to cause intentional collisions and exploit this unintended behavior for malicious purposes.

in this scenario, a malicious user can potentially add the same account number more than once to the list of beneficiary accounts. this is because, upon adding an account, it undergoes verification through a penny drop (i.e., a credit of rs 1 to the account). consequently, a malicious user can exploit this by submitting multiple requests to add the same account simultaneously, resulting in multiple rs 1 credits to the account.

1.avoid mixing data from different storage places.
2.ensure sensitive endpoints make state changes atomic by using the datastore's concurrency features. for example, use a single database transaction to check the payment matches the cart value and confirm the order.
3.as a defense-in-depth measure, take advantage of datastore integrity and consistency features like column uniqueness constraints.
4.don't attempt to use one data storage layer to secure another. for example, sessions aren't suitable for preventing limit overrun attacks on databases.
5.ensure your session handling framework keeps sessions internally consistent. updating session variables individually instead of in a batch might be a tempting optimization, but it's extremely dangerous. this goes for orms too; by hiding away concepts like transactions, they're taking on full responsibility for them.
6.in some architectures, it may be appropriate to avoid server-side state entirely. instead, you could use encryption to push the state client-side, for example, using jwts.

step1:- capture the request post /bank/remittance/add-beneficiary via proxy and send this to intruder.
step2:- now send this same request multiple times simultaneously using intruder attack.
step6:- here, we have sent 6 requests out of which 4 were successful and my same account ending with 6658 has been added 4 times in the beneficiary account list.

here, it is possible for a malicious user to control the source and destination amount in the request post /bank/remittance/initiate-transaction by tampering "source_amount" and "destination_amount" parameter. it gives user to exploit this flaw by sending multiple requests and gaining the differential amount in every transaction which will lead to monetary loss to business.
check the currency conversion at the server side. don't allow user to control the  "source_amount" and "destination_amount" in the initiate transaction request.

step1:- capture the request post /bank/remittance/initiate-transaction via proxy.
step2:- now tamper the parameters "source_amount" and "destination_amount" accordingly and forward this request.
step3:- the request will get successfully processed.
